https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made these many times and everyone loves them. They are not time consuming at all and can be made up two days before needed. Wash mushrooms and twist out stems. Drain in colander. Put mushroom caps on paper towels to drain well. Slice off woody part of stem and put in food processor. Pulse stems until minced. Add 1 Tlbs olive oil to pan and stir-fry minced stems and garlic (minced type from jar)until dry. Add spices. Slightly cool, but while still warm add  cheeses (and a can of drained crab if want). Put a plastic zip lock bag into a bowl and roll back sides- add cream cheese mixture. Snip off one corner and use as a pastry bag to fill mushrooms. If making ahead 1)use only freshest mushrooms you can find, 2)blot off excess water from mushrooms, 3)put them into a non-metalic dish. I sprinkle the tops with shreded (not grated )parmesan cheese. Cover well with plastic wrap and refrig. until ready to bake. (I've made up to two days in advance- without crabmeat though).

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a favorite recipe that I have made several times and I never have any leftovers.  Even my young son loves the flavorfull filling. These are great to bring to get togethers.  I usually prepare the stuffing and put into a ziplock and assemble them when I arrive.  Just snip off the corner of the ziplock, fill the mushrooms like a pastry and pop in the oven. Adjustments I make are I add crabmeat to the mixture which I find adds a little more substance to an otherwise very creamy filling.  I like to sprinkle with parmesan cheese before putting them in the oven which adds a nice touch.  A trick I use is to use smaller mushrooms so there is a good balance between mushroom and the amount of filling.  I tried larger ones one time and it almost seemed like each bite was just a bit too full of creamy mixture.  I also lightly butter the mushrooms before baking which keeps them from drying out.  Last trick is I bake them in mini muffin tin pans.  They hold the smaller mushrooms perfectly and the pans keep the mushrooms from tipping over and rolling around.  The cayenne pepper gives just the perfect amount of kick to this recipe.

text:
Wow, these are ever so good exactly as written!!!  For my family's personal preference, I added the following....  16 oz of ground sausage, increased the Parmesan to 1/2 cup and the garlic to 1.5 tbsp, and then rolled the top of the stuffed mushrooms in the Parmesan cheese and Italian seasoned Panko bread crumbs prior to baking.  Created a great little crunch with wonderful oozy goodness underneath.  Absolutely divine!!!

text:
I made for Christmas dinner appetizer and they were YUMMY! But i also read a lot of the reviews and took some of the advice (and left some). I rated accordingly since i changed it a bit. I used 12 large mushrooms (caps about 2" wide) as the recipe called for as well as the the whole pkg of cream cheese and it was just right. Next time, though, I will use bite size smaller mushrooms but double the amount of mushrooms to make it easier to eat as a appetizer. Used olive oil instead of vegetable oil and  added to the original ingredients for the filling: 2 stalks green onions (minced and cooked with the garlic and mushroom stems), a bit more parmesan (used fresh grated parmesano reggiano), a bit of garlic powder, 1 crisp, crumbled bacon and about a cup of cooked dungeoness crab. I dunked the mushroom caps in melted butter & lemon before filling, sprinkled with more parmesan and baked in a mini muffin pan. (Beware: if the mushrooms don't fit all the way into the muffin pan, they will come out shaped like muffins! It is kind of cute though.) Cooked for 20 mins and they came out beautifully! Everyone loved them! The parmesan topping gave it that extra crunch too! And love the heat the Cayenne leaves after you eat it. Will make (my new revised recipe again!) Thanks!

text:
This was my first time making stuffed mushrooms and after reading several of the reviews I decided on how I would make mine. The full amount of cream cheese was enough for 24 mushrooms and I placed a bit of chopped proscuitto in the bottom of each mushroom before placing the cheese mixture on top (which was wonderful). I then sprinkled garlic and herb bread crumbs over them and drizzled melted butter over all. Baked for only 15 minutes and broiled for the last 5. They were wonderful. I plan on making these when my Mom and Grandmom come to visit in the fall. Thanks a bunch!

text:
Excellent recipe.  I doubled the filling and used 24 oz fresh mushrooms and it filled them almost perfectly.  I also added  a dash of Worcestershire sauce while cooking the stems and 1/3 cup of crumbled bacon to the cream cheese mixture.  Just before baking, I sprinkled with breadcrumbs and dipped the mushroom caps in melted butter so that they wouldn't dry out.  I brought to Thanksgiving as an appetizer and they went in minutes.  Everyone loved the bite that the cayenne pepper added.  Thanks for the great recipe!

Very good recipe! My husband gave it 2 thumbs up, which is HUGE. I followed some other reviewers' suggestions and added 1/4 cup or seasoned breadcrumbs, and cut the cream cheese to about 2/3 what the recipe called for. I also used 2 10oz pkgs of white mushrooms, or about double what the recipe specified. I'm sure adding crabmeat would've made it even better, but i don't think it needs it... i kept the recipe cheap, quick, and easy!

text:
Wonderful--gone in minutes at a party.  1st off, you need 30 button mushrooms (2 pkgs)...I read almost all the reviews, and can't understand who would put all that stuffing in 12 mushrooms.  They complained it was too cream-cheesy...use common sense.  How did anyone even do it...the mushrooms had to be falling over from being so top-heavy.  Second, I added about 10 chives (chopped), omitted the stems, topped with Italian breadcrumbs, and most importantly, tossed the mushrooms in a melted butter/1 tbs lemon juice mixture before stuffing and baking.  As a few suggested, use a Ziploc and cut off a small portion of the corner to stuff...you're done in no time and no mess.  They came out delicious.

text:
I love these little guys. I have to process down to a science. I totally skip the chopping of the stems and cooking them up with garlic. I just throw out the stems. A little trick to keep them from sliding all over the tray is to pop the cookie sheet in the freezer for a few minutes. then after you fill the mushrooms, dip the bottom of the mushroom in melted butter and it will stick to the tray. magic!

text:
I have made this several times and gotten rave reviews! And it is so easy to make! I always end up stuffing an entire package of mushrooms with the amount of filling this makes. I make sure to only include 12 of the stems in the mixture, though, and discard the rest. The last time I made this I mixed everything together as soon as the sauté mixture came off the stove. This really softened the cream cheese and made it much easier to manage. I also put the filling in a ziploc and cut off one edge and squeezed it into each shroom, which was super-easy and fast.

text:
I was looking for something to make for us to snack on while cooking Thanksgiving dinner. I have made these many times, but felt it was too time consuming to make along with everything else! I decided to make a dip out of it by chopping 2 pints of baby portabella mushrooms and cooking as directed in the recipe. I mixed everything together in a small baking dish and baked at 350 for 25 minutes. WOW - it was incredible! I served it with butter crackers! I love the stuffed mushrooms, but will make the dip again if I am running low on time!
*Update - I just made these mushrooms again, omitting the oil (I used Pam instead) and used 4 oz. of light cream cheese and 2 tsp of Parmesan, to lower the fat content. They were still amazing!

text:
Very good - did make some changes, however. First, I was out of cooking spray so I coated the cookie sheet with olive oil. I also used a food processor to mince the garlic and mushroom stems (much faster!) I used olive oil while sauteeing them instead of veg. oil. While mixing everything together, I decided that some LEMON JUICE would be a great addition and trust me, it was. It adds great flavor with the garlic and cayenne. I filled the mushroom caps pretty high... next time, I won't fill so high b/c I love the taste of mushrooms but there was so much filling it was a bit overpowering. The three people I made them for LOVED them, and the 24 mushrooms were gone pretty quickly. I will def. make this one again!

These were great! I changed the recipe slightly by dicing up some mixed dried mushrooms and soaking them in wine. I added a bit of the fresh mushroom stubs, too. I sauteed those in butter and garlic and added a little white wine as well. Then I mixed that with the cream cheese, parmesan cheese along with a touch of italian bread crumbs. Topped with a sprinkle of bread crumbs, cheese and a touch of butter. Cooking them in the mini muffin pan as someone suggested was a great idea. For easy stuffing of the mushrooms, I used a cookie press. I'll be making them agin...

text:
Fantastic! This recipe is a real crowd pleaser.  I tried not to overstuff and saved the extra in the freezer for a quick appetizer if company pops in.  After cutting off stems and preparing the filling, I put the mushrooms (upside down) on a paper towel and microwaved for 12 - 15 minutes. This removes the water and also lessens the cooking time from 25 minutes to 15 - 20 minutes in the oven.  My guests always request these tasty morsels when invited to our home for dinner!

text:
I made these for a birthday party and never got to try one they went so fast.  Best ever is all I heard from everyone.  I followed the recipe as posted except for a tip I got from Cooks magazine.  After the clean and remove stem.  Arrange mushrooms gill side down on coffee filter-lined plate before microwaving to drain moisture from mushrooms.  Heat 5-10 min.  Allow mushrooms to cool before stuffing.  Mushrooms are more firm after baking.

Very good! I brushed the mushroom tops with a bit of EVOO like another reviewer suggested and they didn't dry out or get wrinkly like has happened in the past. I had a few slices of prosciutto on hand, so I chopped them up and added them to the chopped stems and garlic, and sauteed all of it for a minute or two before combining with the cheeses. Fabulous! I don't think I would have liked it as much without the prosciutto or without sauteeing it all before stuffing, which is why I'm giving this recipe 4 stars instead of 5.

text:
I made this recipe for a Christmas Eve dinner party with my friends. I chose it because I have both vegetarian friends and some with gluten-allergies. It was great to find one recipe to fit both dietary needs! I played with the recipe a little bit based on the pictures and my own taste. I doubled the receipe, and sauteed 2 large shallots with the stems and garlic. I added a bunch of sliced green onions into the cream cheese mixture. I actually had forgotten to purchase parmesan cheese prior to making this, so I only had about a tablespoon left. I put that in the filling and proceeded to fill the caps. The next day, I bought the parmesan and covered each mushroom with cheese before baking. These were DIVINE. Everyone except my non-cream-cheese-eating boyfriend loved them. My veg friend even ate one before they were baked and said they were delightful. They're a bit of work (all stuffed mushrooms are) but they are so delicious! AWESOME recipe!

Display Name:

city:

country:

text:
Excellent.  Here's our variation:  Fry 2 strips of thickly cut maple bacon.  Keep the grease (in replacement of the 1 tbsp of veg. oil), set bacon strips aside on paper towel.  Finely chop/mince about 3 tbsp of white onion (yellow would work too).  After I chopped a clove of garlic, it looked to be a little less than the 1 tbsp called for, but still potent enough to do the job for a garlic lover.  The pack of mushrooms we bought had 18 "above average" sized mushrooms.  After frying the garlic, onion, and 12 of the chopped mushroom caps in the leftover bacon grease, we allowed it to cool off, then added the softened cream cheese (8 oz), the 1/4 cup of parm, and the bacon that I had chopped into bits, then added the 1/4 tsp cheyenne, black pepper, AND added 1/4 tsp sea salt bc I noticed it hardly contains any salt outside of the bacon I added and the Parmesan.  Then, mixed it with a wooden spoon and stuffed the 18 medium-large mushrooms I had.  There was still enough stuffing left (after being quite generous) to fill about 3 more mushrooms.  So, if you are making 24, this will certainly do the job b/c I really overstuffed trying to use the stuffing up.  :)  Also, I dipped caps in butter, used glass pan @ 350.  Superb!  The REAL onions are a MUST bc of the flavor and texture it adds.  The first time I ever had stuffed mushrooms, someone had made it using a Lipton Onion Soup mix, which was wonderful, but when I made it the pouch seemed too salty, but doing it manually is perfect.

text:
This is the first time I have ever attempted to make stuffed mushrooms and they were great! There was NO leftovers at my house! There easy, fast, and budget friendly. I did read a lot of the reviews to see what other people did. The most common tip I saw was to dunk the mushrooms in a combo of melted butter and a Tbsp of lemon juice. This was great as it added a little extra kick and kept the mushrooms from drying out. Also I added a dash of Worcestershire and a little bit of chopped green onion. These will definitely be on the table for Thanksgiving this year!

text:
This was so yummy, people couldn't stop eating and commenting on them! This made about 30 or so medium and smallish mushrooms ( I bought a package of Crimini mushrooms at Cosco and used it all up). I read reviews and added chopped green onion to the mushroom stems and garlic as I sauteed them in olive oil. I used both grated and shredded parmesan and left out onion powder as I couldn't find mine, but the green onions made up for it. The cayenne pepper gave it the right kick, and not too spicy. I meant to brush with melted butter as suggested but forgot, and still turned out great. Remember these really shrink in the oven, almost to half-size. I did not top with bread crumbs for gluten-free needs and everyone was happy. Thank you very much. I will try next time with crab.

text:
THESE MUSHROOMS ARE GOURMET RESTAURANT QUALITY.  I always double the filling recipe and buy a huge container of mushrooms from Costco or a wholesale retailer to make a ton, and there are never any leftover!  I've made this recipe just as-is, and I've also made it numerous times adding lump crab meat (don't buy a cheap can...the $3+ cans aren't bad, but anything that costs less than that is disgusting).  The crab ones are always the most popular.  I also add tons of shredded mozzarella cheese that give it a cheesy texture.  Bake these longer than the directions say, however, until they're tender, hot, and have started to release water in the bottom of the pan.  I often buy disposable aluminum pans to bake these in and take them to parties - THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR THIS FLAVORFUL RECIPE!!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614260.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I poured through the reviews and listened to the suggestions before making this.  Tasty, not OMG amazing.  My son liked it very much.  Changes I made:  sauteed in olive oil, not vegetable oil.  Added finely sliced green onions after cooking stems and garlic.  Used chive/onion flavored cream cheese and omitted onion powder.  Added about 1/3 cup bacon bits and extra shredded parmesan cheese.  Didn't have cayenne pepper, so added a very small amount of buffalo wings sauce.  Filled caps with filling to barely above level with the top of the mushroom, dipped in panko bread crumbs and then lightly sprinkled with extra grated parmesan.  Baked thirty minutes, and broiled for the last couple.  This way, the cream cheese flavor was not overpowering, and you could really taste the mushroom.  I used medium-sized mushrooms, so a knife and fork were necessary.

text:
I made these but I'm used to making with breading type stuffing and herbs and a little prosciutto and those are fantastic.  I made this with 4 times the ingredients and 48 mushrooms.  I had at least 10 oz of cream cheese mix left over.  Too much. And that was with generous filling.  I used Fat Free cream cheese.  All in all, the recipe is mostly cream cheese!  That's all you taste and it sits like lead in your gut 2 hours later.  Never again.  I would ditch the cream cheese and go with a bread crumb filling.  Far less fat.  Only people who "love" cream cheese will like this.  Or, maybe cut the cream cheese in half and add bread crumbs to the other half.  Might work.

text:
These are delicious - went fast at Thanksgiving dinner and made again for a holiday party and they were a hit.  I did a couple things recommended by other reviewers. 1. sliced a small amount off the bottom of mushroom to keep it from rolling on the pan. 2. dipped the mushrooms in butter prior to filling (be sure to slice the bottoms first, lol or they will be slippery)! 3. topped with panko bread crumbs mixed with a little melted butter (I think I maybe used 1/4 cup or less of crumbs).  I also kind of patted them down after putting on the crumbs.

text:
I adore stuffed mushrooms, unfortunately most of my family don't really care for mushrooms of any sort. I decided to take a chance and made these for a Thanksgiving appetizer. I followed the recipe with a couple of changes, I added bacon to the filling, and I dipped the mushroom caps into bread crumbs. I was able to make these up two days ahead of time, covered with saran wrap and popped them in the oven right before guests arrived. They came out perfect, the plate was emptied in no time and even the non-mushroom eaters were devouring these, not a single one left, and I doubled the recipe!

text:
Since I had never made these before and planned on taking them to a Christmas party, I made a batch as an experiment to check the seasonings. I followed the recipe exactly and while they were good (even better the day after), I feel they do need a little more flavor. I will add some chives or green onion, maybe some crab meat and definitely some bread crumbs. The amount of cayenne pepper was fine for me. The filling was enough for 24 baby bella mushrooms which were the perfect bite size. Putting the filling in a baggie to pipe the filling into the mushrooms was an excellent idea. Thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These mushrooms are a crowd pleaser. I've never had any left overs and people always ask me for the recipe. I found the original recipe a little bit too cheesy for my liking. I've adjusted the recipe by adding four rashers of finely diced bacon and half-a-cup of finely diced spring onions(use both the white and green parts of the spring onion) into the mixture. Then, I garnish the top of the mushrooms with a sprinkling of finely diced bacon. The bacon becomes golden and crispy in the oven and improves the overall presentation of the mushrooms. Also, I prefer to use small white mushrooms and I find that the mixture is enough to fill 30 to 40 small mushroom caps.

country:

text:
These were amazing!  I made them for "fight-night" last week and everyone loved them.  I was only able to eat one because by the time I got to them, they were all gone :(  I made some minor additions:  I used a food processor to grind the mushroom stems, that way they were really fine.  Sauteed them in butter and added onion powder while sauteing them.  Also used the minced garlic from the jar.  I used a little more cayenne pepper and onion powder than the recipe calls for because, otherwise it was a bit bland for my taste. I used freshly grated parmesano-regiano cheese and added some on top of the mushrooms which gave it a crunchy topping and made it look prettier.  I also added Italian seasoned bread crumbs.  Next time I might try adding bacon.  This is definitely a keeper at my house.

Made this for an office potluck today - and got lots of compliments! text:
I read a lot of the reviews and made this recipe.  These stuffed mushrooms were absolutely delicious.   It was time consuming but worth it.  I added crab meat and used fresh diced onion instead of powdered.  Green onion (scallions) would be delicious too.  I am going to make them again with 2 more additions, spinach and some bread crumbs or Panko.  The filling was runny when the mushrooms came out of the oven, and sort of oozed out of the mushrooms onto our plates. Make no mistake, it was yummy enough hat we were scraping it up off the plate and eating it, but I'd like to firm it up a bit with the bread crumbs so it isn't so messy.

userID:

Display Name:
Ms Jean
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I used olive oil and added a little green onion to the mushroom mixture. I also cut back considerably on the cream cheese, using the spreadable kind from a tub,  probably less than 4 oz. It worked out well, and I don't think I'd want more of it. I used 12 large mushrooms and had no problem using one of those long, skinny teaspoons to fill the mushrooms. I dipped the mushrooms in melted butter with a bit of lemon juice, then sprinkled some lightly with Panko crumbs, some with regular bread crumbs before filling. Drizzled with a tiny bit more of melted butter and topped with more parmesan cheese. Baked 25 min, and they were perfect. The cayenne gave it a nice kick. I can see adding crabmeat or sausage to change it up a bit. Thanks for the excellent recipe, Angie! UPDATE 11/30/14: This time added cooked, crumbled sundried tomato chicken sausage (any type would work) and cutting back even further on the cream cheese. Really like this version even better! The cream cheese acts as a binder, but too much is not appealing to me. GO PATS!!!

text:
These were really great!!! To cut down on calories I used fat free cream cheese instead of regular. An 8-oz package of fat free is only 240 calories while regular is 800 calories, and you'd never be able to tell the difference in this recipe! Other than that I made it exactly as stated and sprinkled some seasoned bread crumbs on top right before baking. A few commenters suggested making these in a cupcake/muffin pan which is what I did, and it made baking/handling them much easier. I've already recommended this to friends and can't wait to make it again!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious! I used mushrooms that were not "fresh" and you couldn't tell a difference--I wouldn't put the mushrooms on a salad but cooked/baked would be okay. I couldn't find the onion powder in the cupboard so I used roasted garlic powder. I also baked the mushrooms in a sprayed mini tin (recommended by another member) and it worked really well. I added the spices to the sauted mushroom stems/garlic and it was very tasty. Don't use a cheap ziploc bag if you are piping the cheese into the mushrooms otherwise it will break--I found out the hard way. Also, push the ziploc bag deep into the mushroom; it will expand and you will be surprised at the amount of cheese it can hold. I will make this again. Thanks for sharing!

text:
I'll make this again, given that everyone really liked them. Nice and flavorful!  I used a 16-oz package of mushrooms that has mainly smaller mushrooms, instead of the really big mushrooms that we can buy loose at the grocery store and it turns out that was a good thing. This stuffing is much better with the smaller mushrooms than it was with the two larger mushrooms that came in the pack. The extra stuffing was a bit overwhelming in the larger mushrooms. I also split out the base recipe into two batches and added 1/2 lb of crumbly fried and drained Jimmy Dean Sausage (regular) to one of the batches. The version with sausage was the bigger hit. Good stuff!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were soo good! I am not an experienced cook, but these were pretty easy and my whole family loved them. I made them for a Thanksgiving appetizer, and I got asked for the recipe! I did make a couple of changes from other reviews I had seen. I doubled the amount of mushrooms from 12 to 24, and it was the perfect amount, it used all of the stuffing and each mushroom was filled perfectly. I still only used 12 stems in the mixture. I also added about 1/8 cup of bread crumbs to the mixture. I dipped the mushroom caps into melted butter before I cooked them to keep them from drying out. I sauteed them in a skillet for about 10 minutes before filling and baking them to let some of the moisture cook out. I baked them for 15 minutes, then took them out and sprinked bread crumbs and parmesan cheese on top and them broiled them for 5 more minutes. They were soo yummy! The only thing I might change next time is to use a little less cayenne pepper than the recipe calls for, the spiciness took away from the rest of the flavors I thought.

text:
ABSOLUTELY mouth-watering!! I made these for today for Thanksgiving and they were demolished! Everyone kept telling me how awesome the filling tasted! I read several suggestions on here and these are the changes I made (which worked out extremely well!) I cut the cayenne in half to 1/8tsp. and I used olive oil instead of vegetable oil. If you follow the exact amount of ingredients, it makes more than enough filling for 24 mushrooms! I bought the little mushrooms so that each bite of the filling wouldn't be too overwhelmingly creamy. The little ones worked out and I ended up with extra filling which tastes amazing even cold. We put the remaining filling out like dip with some crackers after dinner and it was amazing :) I would definitely recommend this recipe to anyone looking for a great response from your guests!

These turned out very well!  I made one slight change.  I cooked the mushroom caps by themselves on a tray upside down until most of the water came out.  I also put a little olive oil and salt+cracked pepper on the caps.  Once the water came out I put the filling in and cooked them until the cream cheese mixture was golden brown.  I made them for a dinner party and they were devoured.  

PS - Any leftover filling tastes great on a cracker!

None
text:
These were a big hit at my wine party this weekend and I highly recommend them because they are tasty, not that difficult, and they are even at room temperature. We made a few modifications: instead of sauteeing the garlic with the diced stems - because garlic will burn way too easily and get bitter - we threw the garlic in for the last 30 seconds.  I didn't have onion powder on hand, so I used minced onions. Also, I know the tag line to this recipe says "no breadcrumbs in this recipe" but we rolled the tops, once stuffed, in panko (japanese style) bread crumbs so that they stuck to the cream cheese and man were they good. Yum!

I had made these a few years ago for a New Years party and got rave reviews so I made them again for a SuperBowl gathering.  These were great and so easy to make.    I did have to warm them back up for about 35-40 seconds via the microwave at one point and that worked out fine. text:
These were the BEST!  My husband is not a mushroom fan and ate 5 of them, then said Id have to make them again!  I mad a couple of changes to the recipe.
I crisped and crumbled  a few slices of bacon and used the bacon grease instead of the oil that the recipe called for to  saute my stems and garlic in.  I also used a food processor to chop the garlic and mushrooms.  I added some minced clams as well and also used a dash of worchestershire sauce as well.  I thought that the cream cheese took a while to mix with the stuffing mixture at first, seeing that its supposed to cool, but after a while it all came together.  I put it in a ziplock baggie and piped it into the caps.  I dipped the caps in butter and sprinkled the stuffing with bread crumbs at the end. they came out fantastic!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are sooo good that I just had to add my comments/modifications (my first review, though I've tried many successes from this sight).  Due to diet restrictions, I did make a couple of substitutions:  olive oil instead of vegestable oil, finely minced onion (1/4 cup or so) instead of onion powder which I did not have, and fat-free cream cheese.  Due to the slightly different consistency, you have to let the cream cheese soften quite a bit (I used my microwave for this).  It takes a bit more work to get it mixed in well with the other ingredients, but the lower calories are worth it.  Also, be sure to bake only until the mushroom caps are wet on the bottom.  Any longer than this and they will shrink, causing the stuffing to coming out the top (and not look as good).  Also, I love the "bite" of the red pepper, but would put in just a bit less for others who don't like as much spice.

text:
Excellent appetizer although I altered this recipe somewhat!  I took the advice of other reviewers and added a little less cream cheese which may not be necessary if you are going to add additional items such as bread crumbs (don't use too much though b/c this will make the mixture very dry) definitely use less than 1/4 cup.  I also used more mushrooms than called for b/c this recipe makes more filling than the amount of mushrooms it calls for. In addition, I added a few spices such as parsley, oregano, and basil.  I then added a little piece of shrimp to each mushroom which really made it that much better! This appetizer is perfect for any party whether casual or elegant!

userID:
400771
Display Name:
BANSREEPARIKH
isPro:
False
followersCount:
13
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
90
favoritesCount:
325
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674145.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe, as written, is okay.  It came out much too stiff and it was difficult to fill the caps because it was so stiff.  I made some changes to the recipe and then it was fantastic!  I used the tub cream cheese, not brick.  This made it creamier.  I added chopped fresh basil (4 large leaves).  Instead of baking the mushrooms at 350 degrees, I set the oven on 'Custom broil' at 420 degrees and broiled them for approximately 20 minutes, until all of the water had evaporated.  Then, to lightly brown the tops, I increased the broil temperature to 500 degrees and watched the browing carefully.  Also, to reduce the amount of water that comes out of the mushrooms, before making the recipe, I peeled the outer skin off of the mushroom caps and let them dry overnight.  This really helped make them less soggy.  Overall, with all of these changes, this was a very delicious recipe and I served it at my Girls Night.  It was devoured by all.

Delicious recipe! I also added crab like others suggested. Everyone loved them! I will say it makes a ton of filling, I don't know what size mushrooms would use up all the filling on just 12. I bought three small packages of white mushrooms and still had leftover filling. The next day I picked up a larger package of mushrooms to finish it off- this time I tossed the mushrooms in butter before adding the filling. The butter was quite the improvement, I would definitely recommend it. Still a very good recipe, as written.

text:
I'm used to making stuffed mushrooms the way my mother did. Take the stems, chop them finely and sauté them in olive oil and butter and then add Italian breadcrumbs, then stuff the caps. I wanted to try something different and possibly better. I came across this recipe and Crystal's suggestion and a few of my own and they were a huge hit!! 

I made these for an app for Easter and everyone loved them. I took Crystal S's suggestion and used Italian sausage meat, fresh garlic and then added some ingredients of my own such as more garlic, sweet onions, baby belle mushrooms chopped up finely into the sautéed ingredients and then added Italian breadcrumbs and one 8oz package of cream cheese. I melted some butter and brushed each mushroom before I filled them and then dipped them into the seasoned panko bread crumbs. 

I can't wait to make them again!!

These were SO delicious and SO easy to make. I didn't use as much cream cheese in order to cut back on some calories. Instead, for the cheese, I used 1/4 cup cream cheese, 1/8 cup Parmesan, 1/8 cup mozzarella, and 2 Laughing Cow garlic and herb wedges. I also mixed 1/4 cup of spinach in. YUM!!!

text:
I just made these for Thanksgiving and they were a huge hit! I doubled the filling and used 24 mushrooms and even had filling left over to make more mushrooms the next day for my own pleasure. I did make a few changes as well, added the green onions to the sauteed stem pieces and garlic so I left out the onion powder. Used the Kraft Three Cheese Blend (parmesan, romano, asiago) and sunflower oil. Helpful hint, use the whipped cream cheese that comes in the tub to cut on prep time and elbow grease.

text:
These were very good & fairly easy just a little time consuming. I made 60 mushrooms for a family christmas party & they were a hit, didn't last long at all! I cut back on cream cheese & added some bread crumbs & crab meat to the "stuffing" I baked them for 15 minutes took them out & sprinkled shredded mozzarella on them & popped them back in for 5 more minutes to melt the cheese. Next time I will cut back on the cayenne pepper it was a little spicy but still good. Although they were gone very quick & we enjoyed them I still prefer a little more stuffing to cheese ratio. But no complaints they were a hit!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing recipe! Few tips for first timers:   1.) It's way better if you can get your hands on the 1oz. individual servings of cream cheese. It's already soft and will save your hand muscles for eating!    2.) Add 1/2 Lb ground turkey, 2 Tbsp bacon pieces, 1 Tsp Italian seasoning, and 1 Tsp garlic salt when cooking mushrooms and garlic for sausage & cream cheese stuffed mushrooms.  3.) If you follow step 2, add 2-3 extra ounces of cream cheese. 
Note: The cayenne pepper is amazing and perfect. Just spicy enough for someone who likes spicy, and not too spicy for someone who just wants a little kick.
Thank you so much for the chance to please my family with this wonderful creation. God bless you!

These are so delicious. I used 6 large portabello mushrooms as there is only 2 of us. I used 4 oz of cream cream, olive oil instead of vegetable oil, added chopped green onions, and some italian bread crumbs  to the stems and garlic. There wasn't really stems on these so i scooped out the insides of the mushrooms. Worked great. Next time I will have a couple extra mushrooms just for chopping. I brushed the outside and inside with melted butter and breadcrumbs. Sprinkled breadcrumbs on top. So good. Will make these for company and parties. Thank you for this recipe.

text:
A delicious recipe! I switched mine up though. I used a container of Feta cheese instead of Parmesan. Also, I added chopped onion and spinach to my mix. Also, I added different herbs such as basil, rosemary, oregano and a hint of onion powder. Mixed it all together, stuffed it in my little caps and baked for the 20 minutes. They were delicious. Unfortunately, I actually have to share them with my friends!

The filling would be good as a chip dip as well with pita chips or bread.

Display Name:
idodough

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was awesome, and so easy to do. As others suggested, I increased the mushrooms to 20 and used only 18 of the steam. I also used only 2/3 of cream cheese. Additions to the recipe were 2 slices cooked bacon, minced, and 2 green onions, also minced but only used lower half. Rolled the tops in panko and dipped in butter like other wrote. MMMM MMMMM MMMM is the best way to describe it. When I cooked it I only did it 10 minutes, go a bit longer if you like, and then broiled for 5. If you are doing this recipe ahead of time I'd prepare the mix and store in a baggie while putting the mushrooms in a container; put in fridge for no more then 2 days. Then when ready bring the mushrooms and mix to room temp. Fill the mushrooms, panko the tops, then dip in butter and cook.

text:
This recipe really tastes like jhony carino's baked stuffed mushrooms. If you don't want the texture to be too much creamy you can substitute some of the cheese with breadcrumbs. I also prefere to use green onion instead of the powder. The green color in the mix makes it more attractive. I also like to add one tea spoon of worstershire sauce. After baking the mushrooms for 15 min I add half cup of cooking cream to the mushrooms and cut one tomato and sprincle it above the mushrooms with some persly. The cream addition makes this recipe a gourmet dish!

text:
Made these for the family Christmas gathering. My brother in-law tasted them as I was bringing them out of the oven. He suggested that I just put them in his car so that the rest of the family did not have to be "subject to the terrible tasting stuffed mushrooms"-yeah right! I too used 3x the amount of mushrooms and it came out perfect with the amount of filling. I did not think the cayeene pepper was to much, it gave them a nice "kick"! I did not measure the parm cheese. I used more than it called for (can never have too much cheese!) and added a can of drained crab meat. These were a big hit and ZERO left over. I made them up the day before and they kept overnight in the fridge just beautiful!I also set a cooling rack in the pan to bake them on as to not have the shrooms sit in the juice as they baked. This is one that will get made again and again for sure!

text:
This was delicious, but I changed it a fair amount using what I had on hand.  I substituted Laughing Cow lite cheese wedges for the cream cheese.  I would have added crabmeat if I'd had it, and I used a mixture of shredded parmesan & shredded colby jack (1/4 C ea) to 1/2 C breadcrumbs.  I also added 1 raw egg to the mixture for moisture & binding.  This mixture stuffed 20 large mushrooms and they were wonderful!

This I think was the best stuffed mushrooms I have ever had. I made them for my family and friends and they all went nuts over them.  My Mom hates mushrooms and just loved them.
I followed the recipe exactly maybe added a little more cheese. I put it on low when doing the garlic(so it would not burn) and chopped stems. Thank you so much for this wonderful recipe!

These mushrooms slightly reminded me of the 'Shrooms that are on the menu at Houlihan's restaurant.  I followed the advice from others and added the mushroom pieces to the olive oil and minced garlic.  Added the dry spices and cooked until almost dry. I served with a mixture of horseradish and mayo.

MEGA 5 Stars!  I cooked 3 slices of bacon then took it out and chopped it up really fine- cooked a small chopped onion with some garlic in the bacon grease and proceeded from there with 1/2 a block of cream cheese, 1/2 cup chicken broth, and about 1/4 cup seasoned bread crumbs.  I also blanched the mushroom caps (I used baby portabellas) in about 1 cup of chicken broth for about 5 minutes and drained them on paper towels before stuffing them.  These were out of this world!!!!!!!  MEGA, MEGA 5 stars!!  Thanks for the starting off MY stuffed mushrooms!!!!!!!!

text:
The name says it all - these are truly mouth-watering. Although they are a bit time-consuming, I don't mind with a delicious outcome like this. I made about 25 mushrooms last night; they tasted fantastic hot out of the oven. I followed some other reviewers' example and sprinkled the tops with Parmesan cheese and breadcrumbs. Sprayed with butter-flavored cooking spray. I think they taste just as good as The Olive Garden's stuffed mushrooms (you can add clams to the stuffing to make it even more like theirs), only better because you know exactly what went into them, AND they're not swimming in a butter sauce. My family loved them. I'll definitely make these again and again. Thanks so much for the recipe!

Edit: I just made these again, with great results and great comments from the lucky eaters!

I had no leftovers and will definitely be making this again soon.

text:
These were absolutely fabulous!  I don't like fresh mushrooms because they taste too strong, so I experimented with the everyday variety.  I made 3 dozen Christmas Eve, and barely rescued 1 dozen of those to serve for Christmas dinner.  They are easy to make, easy to reheat, and easy to serve.  I took another reviewer's advice and used some plain bread crumbs, and it turned out perfect.  I'm making more for New Year's, but omitting the cayenne on half for those of us who can't take the heat.  Had lots of leftover stuffing, but hubby quickly found a use for it!

These mushrooms are indeed "mouth watering".  I took the advice that I read in the reviews and add flavor by coarsely chopping the mushroom stems (not finely) and  I sauted the garlic and stems with half butter/oil, adding a spinkle of Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper.  I added 1/4 cup of Italian bread crumbs and a little more fresh black pepper to the mixure Topped each mushroom with bread crumbs and parmesan cheese.
Very good recipe.  Thank you :o)

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2015-12-19T20:31:49.943
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
17055921
Display Name:
Kathy Kingseed
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
50
favoritesCount:
500
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6896640.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I usually prepare the stuffing and put into a ziplock. Just snip off the corner of the ziplock, fill the mushrooms like a pastry and pop in the oven. Adjustments I make are I add sausage to the mixture which I find adds a little more substance to an otherwise very creamy filling. I like to sprinkle with parmesan cheese before putting them in the oven which adds a nice touch. A trick I use is to use smaller mushrooms so there is a good balance between mushroom and the amount of filling. I also lightly butter the mushrooms before baking which keeps them from drying out. Last trick is I bake them in mini muffin tin pans. They hold the smaller mushrooms perfectly and the pans keep the mushrooms from tipping over and rolling around. The cayenne pepper gives just the perfect amount of kick to this recipe.

text:
Exellent... had some cream cheese mixture left over so I took bread, cut off crusts, flatten with rolling pin, spread mixture fairly thick on bread, roll up, cover outside of roll with butter then freeze.  Take frozen rolls, slice into bite size pieces, place on cookie sheet so you can see the spiral then bake @350 for 10 -15 min.  YUM.  I used both rye and Italian bread. Both were good.

text:
Loved It and so did my family! Not many modificaciones i had to make! Depending on the size of the mushrooms, you may have some StuffIt lector over. I did not use the entire 1/4 cup of parmesian cheese and instad of mixing It into the mixture, i sprinkled It o top. Also i did not have cayenne pepper, but I replaced it with chili power and it was just as good! Anything that leaves a little heat is a perfect substitute. Lastly I crumbled three slices of bacon into the mixture for my meat loving family. Next time I make these I will cut off a little of the bottom to keep the mushrooms from tipping over, but it was a great recipe that you can really put your own spin on, love it!
Review:
Rating:
2

text:
My husband said these were the best mushrooms he ever ate! Really simple to make. I opted to use the Wildtree Garlic Grapeseed Oil to cook the garlic & mushroom bits instead of just vegetable oil, which added even more garlic flavor. Also, I thought the cayenne pepper added the perfect amount of kick. I topped mine with some Italian bread crumbs and shredded Parmesan before baking. And, I also dipped the mushroom caps in melted better before baking.  I will definitely be making these again! Thanks!

text:
I just made these last night.  I halved it for 4 people. Followed recipe exactly, but used the 1/3 lower fat cream cheese and added crumbled bacon from one slice. VERY good, but a little too "cream-cheesy".  I think next time I would add some Panko and one more slice of bacon crumbled up.  I did add Panko on the top, then added melted butter per another reviewer's advice. Baked these for 18 min, then broiled for a minute. Everyone loved these!

I got a HUGE response for these when I served them.  I used olive oil instead of vegetable and real onion instead of powder.  Per other reviews, I also gave the mushrooms a fresh lemon juice and melted butter bath before I filled them and I used a mini muffin pan.  My only recommendation is that the ratio is off for white button mushrooms.  I could have filled twice the number of mushrooms with the filling.  Buy extra mushrooms!

text:
This is a great base recipe for stuffed mushrooms!  This is such a great party appetizer because they seem fancy and everyone is always impressed, but they are so simple!  I like to add 1/2 pound of pork sausage, browned and crumbled, I replace the onion powder with 1 finely diced minced onion.  I sauté the onion, mushroms stems, and garlic together before adding everything else.  I also like to sprinkle panko crumbs or even crushed ritz crackers on the top because it looks pretty.  I recommend these!  Get ready to impress!

This is one of my favorite recipes. I usually also add in minced onion and extra onion and garlic powder for extra flavor. A good recommendation: add sliced roma tomatoes on top prior to baking, and 5-10 minutes before they have finished fully cooking, add goats cheese on top of the tomato, switching it to broil so that the goats cheese browns on top. I also like to add fresh basil leaves on top once finished cooking. So delicious!

text:
I see I am way, way out in the minority here but we really didn't like these. The cream cheese was too much for stuffed mushrooms, it was like I crammed a dip into a mushroom cap and warmed it. I saw another reviewer also in the minority mention they preferred bread-y stuffed mushrooms: that must be it, I've eaten these in lots of restaurants and never have I been less impressed than these I took the time to make. I think I must like when seasoned breadcrumbs soak up the moisture from the sauteed mushroom pieces and caps and make a filling. I guess I'll look for other recipes and go from there. Thanks for sharing though, I can tell these are well-liked so I went with 2 stars.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a keeper! Easy and very tasty.  I chose this recipe because I need to eat gluten free and didn't have any GF bread crumbs for the traditional recipe.  I made 18 generously stuffed medium-large mushrooms and even decreased the cream cheese to 6 oz.  I also used garlic powder instead of fresh garlic. I was also short on time and it worked up very quickly.  Twenty minutes at 350F was just right - we like a little "bite" left to our mushrooms (not mushy).   The cayenne pepper is a must .  If you're afraid it will be too spicy, just use less.  I only used about a pinch of cayenne and it still gave a nice contrast to the cheesiness.

text:
I've made these stuffed mushrooms many times now. Each time trying something a little different. 
The version which has gotten the best response was one in which I added shredded carrot and zucchini and finely chopped green onion to the standard filling. All sauteed along with the mushroom stems before adding to the mix. Not only do they taste amazing they have a little more flavor and texture umph. Shredded carrot and zucchini are now standards in all the stuffed mushrooms I make. 
Last week I made some using clams diced finely. To that I added a small dab of ricotta cheese in the botton then stuffed as usual however I did omit the cayanne pepper in this one. Another try included sprinkling a small amount of dry packaged italian dressing mix into the cream cheese along with the addition of finely chopped spinach. Again I omitted the cayanne pepper in this batch.

I personally have a huge distaste for mushrooms but decided that these would make a great Valentines day surprise for my boyfriend who rarely gets to eat home-cooked mushrooms. The recipe was really simple and quick to make, which as a new cook was fantastic! The leftover stuffing from the mushrooms was used on a bagel and devoured instantly while the mushrooms were in the oven. text:
I wasn't overly happy with this recipe especially for the prep work. I was going to give it a 3 because I did eat some of these mushrooms, but there are so many changes I would make. I like to try recipes as they are written so that I know what I would differently. 1. I would definitely add the bread crumbs, crab or sausage to the mix. It just lacked substance. 2. I felt it also needed a little saltiness to the mix.Maybe a 1/8 tsp of salt? 3. I thought it also needed a little savory flavor. Maybe a little Worcestershire sauce or bacon. 4. The spice of the Cayenne pepper took away from the flavor. I would cut it back by half. 5. I would also add bread crumbs to the top of the mushrooms and broil for a few min as they needed a bit of a crunch. I would make a variation of this recipe.

text:
This recipe is amazing and always a sure fire hit. After making it so many times to it's exactness, I started making my own variation on it. I add one small finely chopped onion and sautee that with the garlic and mushrooms until everything is nice and brown. Once I mix the veggies with the cream cheese, I add a few more dashes of onion powder as well as garlic powder. Then, the last 10 minutes of baking, I add grated parmesan on top along with shredded parmesan. They turn out GREAT! Make sure to set aside some for yourself, because they will be gone before you know it!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Yum! I did make some improvements: 

- put the mushrooms in the oven, stem side down, for ten minutes in a pan w/ a rack on the bottom. This allowed my mushrooms to release some of their water. I hate stuffed mushrooms that are watery. 

- added about 1/4 lb of well chopped hot Italian sausage to the mix. 

- took 1/4 cup of panko crumbs and browned them in a pan w/ about 2 tsp butter and 1 tsp of the sausage drippings. I sprinkled these on top, then threw on some parmesan. I used shaved parmesan for more substance (larger pieces). 

My husband said they were the best he's ever had, anywhere.

text:
I made these for my boys and I for our "Meatless Monday" meal. They raved about them! I doubled the recipe, and we had no leftovers. I thought they were yummy, but that maybe there was too much cream cheese. I could not point my finger on it on what my taste buds were trying to tell, but they were still good. Did I mention there was no leftovers? I did leave out the cayenne, since I have a boy who is slightly sketchy on "hot" items. I also had some onion I needed to use up, so I tossed those in with the garlic. Will make again.

text:
A little spicy for our taste.  They did bake perfectly in a regular muffin pan.  I brushed the mushrooms with olive oil.  I used a bag to squeeze the mixture into the mushroom.  I recommend not swirling it in because when it comes out baked it looks a little yucky.  It was not brown at 20 mins so I broiled it for 2.5 mins.  It really needed something on the top for garnish....like bread crumbs.

text:
Stupendous! This is my go to appetizer: easy to make, EVERYONE loves them. When me girlfriends come over there is always a special request for these...  I feel like they get soggy and fall over when I baked them as such, so I wrap foil tightly over the open top of a pan and poke holes in the foil and place the filled mushrooms on the foil so any leaking liquid can strain into the pan.. sometimes I mix in imitation crab into the cheese mixture before filling, pretty tasty that way too (a little lighter on the cheese, and changes the texture a little bit).  Bon appétit!!

text:
Was a pretty good recipe. Although the changes I would/did make: I used 12 gourmet stuffing mushrooms, I would use half the oil since it didn't evaporate completely and I had to spoon out the excess, I would use garlic powder next time since the minced was slightly overpowering, I only used half of the cream cheese and STILL had leftover stuffing mixture, I didn't time the baking... I just "eyed" it, and when there was what seemed to be about 2 minutes of baking time left, I added a good size pinch of shredded cheddar cheese to the top of each one and pushed it down slightly so it stayed on top... :) For my first stuffed mushroom recipe, I was pleased! :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Fast. Easy indicator when done. Available and cheap ingredients. Forgiving proportions and great as a base recipe. Better and cheaper than any restaurant. 1. Instead of adding cream cheese at once, do so slowly to get a soft but firm consistency (no mush). 2. Easy to experiment on using diff vegetables, fillings (I used canned crab meat), spices and cheeses (why not try with salmon-flavored or veggie-flavored cream cheese?). 3. If you have extra stuffing, it already has cooked ingredients and can be used on bread as a tasty snack. 4. Good idea to brush mushrooms with butter. 5. Take breadcrumbs (I prefer panko)  and put in a small bowl and if your mushrooms aren’t too overflowing, turn it over gently and place on dish so that the crumbs stick easily to the mushroom.

text:
These are pretty good as is.  I have made them 3 times, though and discovered this last time that brushing some melted butter on the bottoms of each cap really improves the taste and texture.  My guests who've had them both ways agree.  Also, I use the smaller mushrooms - I made them the first time with "super stuffers" and they were difficult to eat, the smaller ones can just be popped in whole.  I still use 12 stems, but the filling goes a lot farther - I got about twice as many stuffed mushrooms (though they did disappear much faster!).  Overall, a very tasty recipe!

text:
The best! It's better eaten fresh from the oven.  Like others, I added 1/4 cup bread crumbs (in my case panko) to the cream cheese. Then I pressed  the stuffed mushroom unto real bacon bits and then to a plate of panko.  It gave a bit of crunch and it browns well.  No need for oil spray.  The bacon bits and panko adheres easily to the cream cheese mixture. Looks pretty!

text:
These were a big hit at our house!  I made one substitution.  Instead of cream cheese I used Tofutti's Better Than Cream Cheese product (Whole Foods carries it).  Before you say EWWWW I have to tell you that my cheese loving husband also said EWWWW.  He had it in his mind not to like these before I made them.  To please me, he tried them. And HE LOVED THEM AND WANTED MORE (so I shared the last one with him)!  We could not tell a difference between cream cheese and this product so I felt I had to share that with you all.  No dairy, No Butterfat, No Cholesterol, No Hydrogenated Oils.  A 2 tbsp serving is 60 calories, 5g fat (2g Sat.), 120mg sodium, 2g carb, 1g protein.  Compare that to regular cream cheese which has 83 Cal per oz, 8g fat per oz (5g Sat.),25mg Cholesterol, 188mg Sodium. The carbs and protein are very similar. If you're a Vegan (we're not but we're trying to cut down on our dairy consumption) or you're allergic to dairy or you're lactose intolerant you can still have these mushrooms and not miss out on anything.  Thanks for sharing the recipe Angie!

text:
SO DELICIOUS!! My husband stated that these were the best stuffed mushrooms he had ever eaten- even better than his own mother's (whose are also very tasty). I like to have meat in my stuffed mushrooms, so I fried up a little extra lean ground beef. I went ahead and just added the all the ingredients to the meat while it was cooking, then cooled it off, and mixed in the room temp. cream cheese. I would also recommend to use smaller mushroom caps as other reviewers have suggested- unless you absolutely LOVE cream cheese, the smaller mushrooms can balance the mushroom/cream cheese flavor. YUM!!!!

country:
None
text:
I made this last night for my "Girls Night In" wine/appetizer party.  I kept it very close to the original recipe.  The only substitute I made was olive oil for the veg oil and because of many previous reviews I also halved the cayenne pepper thinking it was going to be "hot."  I didn't taste the cayenne at all so next time will use the full amount. I also put just a tiny pinch of bread crumbs on the tops.  The mixture filled 36 small button mushrooms and there was still plenty left over (that I'll use later today with the rest of the mushrooms).    I also put the mushrooms on a cooling rack on top of a cookie sheet as previous reviewers had mentioned.  This not only made the clean up a breeze but also kept the mushrooms from getting all soggy on the bottom.  It only took the suggested 20 minutes to cook and I also broiled them at the end for 3 minutes to give them added crunch.  It has a great flavour and my friends liked it as much as I did.  There were only three of us and we ate every last shroom!  This recipe is definitely a keeper.

text:
Very good! Although I doctor it up ALOT! 1st of all, I use baby portabellas. I use finely chopped onions and a slice of red or yellow pepper along with the minced garlic. Sautee it all in butter. (Dieters beware!) Then after cooling, add only 2 oz. cream cheese, & more mozzarella than parmasian. I cut it all in half & add crab meat & more red pepper to half of it. Broil for the last few minutes. Overall it really takes about an hour to prepare & cook, but worth it!

text:
Yum!  I made them for boxing day at my sister-in-law's and everyone loved them!  We were traveling, so I made the filling up ahead of time.  I took the stems out and only washed them.  I rewrapped the caps and didn't wash them til I was ready to cook them. I didn't have onion powder, so I diced up fresh onion and cooked it along with the garlic and stems.  Once that was cooked, I split the mixture into two separate bowls and after it was cooled, I added 1/2 of each of the ingredients to each bowl.  To one of the bowls I added a can of cocktail shrimp and a can of crabmeat.  I covered the bowls, kept them chilled, and cooked the mushrooms 3 days later.  They were fabulous. I will definitely be making these again!  Bravo!

text:
This recipe is AMAZING!! I make it all the time for company. It's super easy to put together and can be made last minute. I do make a few adjustments though. Instead of using onion powder, I finely chop up a sweet onion and throw it in with the mushroom stalks and garlic. That totally makes it. I also substitute the cayenne pepper for "Sriracha" or "Asian Rooster Sause". It's cheaper then the pepper and gives the mushrooms an amazing taste with a little kick!! I sometimes make a double batch of the filling and use it as a dip with Ritz crackers.. LOVE IT!!!

country:
None
text:
I followed this recipe kind of loosely.. I used only 3oz of cream cheese and approximate amounts for the other ingredients. I also used garlic powder instead of minced garlic since I couldn't be bothered with worrying about it burning while it was sauteed with the mushroom stems. I mushed the cream cheese together with the spices and stems in a Ziploc bag instead of trying to mix it in a bowl, and used the Ziploc bag as a pastry bag to fill the mushroom caps.

Even with my modifications, this recipe is fantastic! I noticed that liquid formed under the caps after only about ten minutes but I let them cook the whole twenty and they came out great. Also, as mentioned in other reviews, 8oz seems like a bit much. 3oz filled 13 mushrooms for me!

text:
Really good.  After reading people's comments about time consuming here's a little tip.  Any time I stuff something whether it's eggs, jalsapenos etc.  I mix everything in a food processor and then put it in a gallon size freezer bag, snip a corner of the bag and simply pipe it in.  It's fast easy and less messy.  Great recipe, thanks for sharing.

text:
It doesn't get much better than these.  My kids loved them, my boyfriend who is not a huge mushroom fan loved them and so did I!  I used light cream cheese.  I didn't have quite enough parmesean so I added some shredded mozerella to make up for it.  I also used all my cayenne on the red beans so I used chinese "rooster sauce" instead.  I was surprised that it said to chop the mushroom stems but did it. I used my hand held food chopper and it worked great to mince them up finely and boy did they look and smell great when cooked with the oil and garlic!  That alone would be great on pizza!  Excellent recipe, will make these many times again.

These were so good! I loved them. I did a couple changes. Since I was only making them for myself, I used 10 small mushrooms and only 4 oz of cream cheese. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Outstanding recipe!  I made these mushrooms for a family dinner and all mushroom lovers raved.  I found that one batch of filling filled approximately 18 fairly large mushrooms (with slight modifications).  Also, I added 1 T. of finely minced sweet onion to the mushroom sautee and used half olive-oil and half butter.  (I still added the onion powder although I used minced onions, too.)  I made 2 separate batches of filling:  one crab and one bacon.  For the crab filling, I added two 6 oz cans of well-drained flaked crab.  For the bacon filling, I added 5 thick-cut strips of finely chopped smokey bacon (I also added 1 tablespoon of bacon fat).  I used my Pampered Chef self-releasing scoop to put generous portions of filling on the mushrooms, then I sprinkled them with a very fine coating of unseasoned bread crumbs and parmsan cheese.  Yum!  One last note:  although we love spicey foods, we thought the cayenne added too much hotness and actually detracted from the other savory flavors in the recipe.  I suggest omitting it.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Now I know why so many people reviewed and loved this recipe. It is special. It is delicious with a few tweaks. I prepared the filling (minus crab) the day before event. For a bridal shower with 25 people, I used 1-40oz container of large shrooms(from Costco) and 1-16oz. smaller shrooms. I then only doubled the recipe. I used a generous amt of garlic (2-3T.) and sauteed stems, garlic, and 3 thinly sliced green onions. Let cool and then mixed in crm chs and spices, inc 4 dashes worcestershire.  Meanwhile, b/c the shrooms were large, I precooked them for 8-10m. at 400. Then cooled (drain out liquid).  The day of event, mixed in crab, assembled, sprinkled with parm chs, & baked. They were great!!!!!

text:
This recipe will be a permanent fixture in my recipe box! Wow! They take a little time, but soooo worth it. I did sub the minced garlic for 4 fresh garlic cloves, pressed. I also didn't have the cayenne, so I used some dry pico de gallo seasoning that was in the cabinet and it still turned out great! I have company coming in soon, so I'm going to mix the stuffing ahead so I can just fill the caps and pop into the oven. Wonderful!

text:
I made these for a dinner party and everyone loved them.  I used 18 medium sized cremini mushrooms instead of button mushrooms because I think creminis have a better flavor. I arranged them on a serving platter with a bunch of fresh parsley for decoration.  This appetizer is a bit labor intensive, so make the stuffing ahead of time and chill until you are ready to stuff the mushrooms.

text:
These are awesome, which is obvious by all the great reviews.  I've made these several times and they're better each time I make them.  The first time I made them, I followed the recipe exactly.  Now I just guess the measurements and taste the cream cheese mixture to make sure I like it.  It's so easy to adjust this recipe so that it suits your tastes.  Sometimes I sprinkle with bread crumbs or parmesan.  My next goal is to figure out how roll them in bread crumbs and fry them, like the 'Shrooms at Houlihan's.  I love this recipe, but Houlihan's has the best stuffed mushrooms ever!

These were so tasty that I'm adding them to my Thanksgiving menu this year!  I took other reviewer's advice and made only half of the filling.  I was still able to generously fill 22 medium sized mushrooms.  Once the filling was in each mushroom I dipped them in seasoned breadcrumbs and sprinkled them with paprika.  Yummy!  Lastly, they freeze great, just freeze before cooking and pop in oven whenever you need them.

text:
If I make this recipe again, I will change a few things.  (1) Substitute part of the cream cheese for another kind of cheese -- there was way too much of this thick cheese.  (2) Roll the mushroom caps in melted butter before baking, as many stuffed mushroom recipes call for -- the caps were too dry, I guess because of their size and thickness.  (3)  More spices to zing up the flavor.  Don't get me wrong, the recipe wasn't bad, it just wasn't what appeals to me.

None
country:
None
text:
This is one of my go to recipes for side dishes, since mushrooms are one of my favorite foods. I use white pepper instead of black and simply double the measurement it calls for. I also add one or two jalapeño peppers for a little more heat (I deseed them and use about half the ribs), and sauté them with the mushroom stems and garlic. I always use my food processor to mince the stems, garlic, and jalapeños. Since I always have quite a bit of filling left over, I always buy mini bell peppers to fill as well. Just cut them in half, fill them, and cook right along with the mushrooms for the regular time. It never fails to come out beautifully. Thanks for the recipe!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-04-23T18:27:00.61
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4428134
Display Name:
Bob
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
10
favoritesCount:
257
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great base recipe and flexible enough to accept all sorts of filling options and works decently for peppers too. 

I added 1/2 Tb Garlic paste to the diced stems about halfway through the saute instead of minced whole garlic. I left out the cayenne at the request of one of the guests. I also added about 1/3 cup bacon bits just because I had them handy, and about 1 Tsp toasted onion powder, and about 1 Tb finely chopped fresh parsley.  I used twelve 2"- 3" portabellas, and had enough left over to fill 3 jalapenos sliced lengthwise with seeds and membrane removed. After removing from the oven I sprinkled everything with fresh shredded parmesan and sprinkled a little smoked paprika on top, mainly for presentation. The jalapenos were as well received as the mushrooms, probably . because the mushrooms were not spicy at all. 

Other things you may want to try in the filling
Pimentos
roasted red peppers
popcorn shrimp
crab meat
different cheeses with the cream cheese
black olives
finely diced shallots
Capers (beware of over salting)
anchovy paste (beware of over salting)
Fresh chives
Fresh Basil
Poppy seeds

Just a wonderful base recipe to add to your toolbox.

text:
These really are mouth-wateringly delicious! I did make some minoe changes.  I added 8 oz. of ground sausage. I added a minced shallot to the garlic and sauted in the sauge fat, not oil. I also deglazed the pan with 1/4 cup of dry white wine, allowing it to reduce by half. I also used chive and onion cream cheese. I sprinkled the top w/ a romano and bread crumb mixture. After filling 25 baby Bella mushrooms, I still had some filling left. I made mimi tartlets with it. Also, I only tasted one so far! They're actually for tomorrow. Definitely will make again!

None
text:
I left off the topping part because I did not have any parmasean cheese on hand. While these were really good, I felt they lacked a bit of flavor depth. They essentially tasted like a mushroom just stuffed with cream cheese, with a tiny kick from the cayenne pepper, even after adding small bits of green onion. Next time, I might consider adding small bits of finely chopped bacon and more spices. Also, I used more than the 12 mushrooms because there was extra filling. I ended up with a total of 18 mushrooms in the recipe. Overall, a good base recipe to start.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2017-01-19T20:00:12.507
helpfulCount:

userID:
13808708
Display Name:
K.J.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are the BEST. No more marinated mushrooms with steaks for me. I served them with steaks for NY's dinner and the company loved them. I followed the advice of several reviewers and baked them in  the muffin pan, with muffin papers. I cleaned them, put the cleaned mushrooms in a ziploc bag and then into a rectangular ziploc container to protect them from breaking in the full refrigerator. I did not have the room to store them stuffed; so,  after  mixing the filling I stored that in a separate ziploc bag. That made for no cleanup and easy filling.  
I used Pecorino Romano instead of Parmesan as my niece doesn't like Parmesan, and left out the cayenne as my nephew-in-law doesn't like spicy food. I also followed the advice to add the cream cheese to the still warm skillet and mushrooms and it was very easy to mix. It's well worth it to individually pick 12 mushrooms out of the loose mushroom bin so that there isn't as much size variation and you get exactly 12. They reheat well, and they are also good cold. No crabmeat is needed in them, they are perfect as is, and are now my go-to mushroom recipe. Thank you Angie Gorkoff!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
The recipe is great as it is, I'm sure. However, since 1) I didn't have a couple of the ingredients, and 2) I was feeling a little lazy, I did change the recipe just a tad. First off, I didn't have any fresh garlic so I opted to use about a 1/2-1 tbsp (use your judgement here) of garlic powder. I omitted the onion powder for the same reason. I did not bother with sautéing the stems. I just discarded them. I used a baking dish and painted the bottom. I had some plain Panko breadcrumbs and poured them in a small bowl and dipped/rolled the tops of the stuffed mushrooms to coat and placed them in the baker. Then I brushed melted butter on top of the Panko crusted mushrooms and baked at 350 x 20 minutes. I did end up having to broil at the end of the cooking time to achieve browning. They turned out great!

city:

country:
None
text:
This was my first time making stuffed mushrooms and they were a big hit.  Since I don't like food with a kick, I left out the cayenne pepper.  After stuffing the mushrooms I thought they looked too plain...white filing on white mushroom. Therefore I chopped up some green onion and sprinkled it on the top of the filling. On half of the mushrooms I put some paprika to add more color.  I used a long handled infant spoon to remove the stems of the mushrooms. It worked perfectly!! I used the same spoon to fill them.  I made half a recipe of filling and filled 18 smaller mushrooms. I bought a package of white mushrooms and picked out the smaller ones. The contributor of this recipe must have used very large mushrooms to get only twelve out of a full recipe of filling.  Next time I make these, and there will be a next time, I will add more garlic.

text:
I tried this recipe and it turned out very good.  My husband said it was a keeper.  I added Laotian chile paste 'cause I was out of cayenne.  I added bread crumbs on top to get a crunchy taste, and I also added a couple of capers on top at the end.  I am going to do this recipe again and this time I will add the crumbs and capers at the start.  I also used 4  oz. of soy cream cheese.  It was no different than regular cream cheese.  I also added finely chopped onions (instead of onion powder) and half a red pepper.  Thank you so much for such an easy basic recipe that we can modify as we wish.

userID:
4905397
Display Name:
Keary Ann
isPro:

2

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2969809.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are really good--I liked them because they were lighter than many stuffed mushrooms, which are heavy on the bread. I will add a light dusting of breadcrumbs on top next time, just to give them a little more texture.  I added some Italian seasoning blend, and increased the spices a bit (about 1/2 teaspoon total of each).  This was just enough to give them a little kick, but the flavor was still cooled by the cream cheese and mushroom flavors.  Everyone loved them. Just make more than you think you need, as they disappear very quickly!
Review:

Don't let the four stars fool you, this recipe is AWESOME! I try to rate recipes as written and this one could use bread crumbs to make it truly 5 stars but I was super impressed. I made these on a trial run last night and they were gone in no time flat! Next time I will add breadcrumbs and maybe bacon for him, but I had NO complaints other than that they ran out too fast.

This is a delicious recipe.  I have followed it exactly, and it's amazing.  I have also tried it with lots more mushroom added to the filling.  And that's really good too, more mushroom flavor.  I put it in a ziplock bag and snip off a corner so I can pipe the filling into the mushrooms. I always have left over filling.  I just freeze it and use it again within a week or so.

text:
Delicious! I used 24 smaller mushrooms to make more finger food like. Used a baggie to pipe the cream mixture in the shrooms. I made the day before, put on a baking sheet covered with parchment, covered with foil and put in the fridge. When I was ready to heat the next day I removed the foil, topped with parmesan cheese and breadcrumbs, and dipped caps in melted butter. Next time I think I'll add panko breadcrumbs for more of a crunch! Everyone loved them!

text:
Yummy!  Ended up with waaay too much cream-cheese mixture after stuffing my mushrooms... I will use only 1/3 of a package of cream cheese next time so there's no waste.  SUGGESTION:  When mixing the cream-cheese mix, throw it all in a Ziploc and 'mush it around' until mixed.  Then cut the end off and "cake-frost" the mushroom caps.  Makes it so easy!  No need for a spoon.  And you can get a cute little twirly at the top of each cap!   :)

text:
These were pretty darn good, but I'm awfully glad I added extra ingredients to the cream cheese. I used about twenty / twenty-five mushroom stems that were very meaty and cut up a few whole mushrooms as well, four cloves of garlic, about 2/3 C Parmesan and Asiago cheeses, and doubled the onion powder. This was still very cream cheesy. Next time, I think I'll add some chopped yellow or green onion, and perhaps even some cooked ground sausage.
These are very filling! I made a bunch of these and we had them with meatless marinara and penne pasta. Yum!

This recipe is amazing! But I have changed it quite a bit since 8oz of cream cheese is enough for as much as 5 dozen mushrooms depending on how creamcheesy you want to make the stuffing mixture.  I go with the spices of the recipe and add spinach and onion to the mix when I'm cooking the garlic & mushroom.  This has made the flavor of the filling so much better and them healthier in cutting the amount of cream cheese per mushroom and I personally like the texture better too! Excellent suggestions in other reviews!

text:
I wasn't crazy about this recipe.  The next time I try it I think I'll make a few changes.  This recipe calls for too much cayenne.  The amount tasted fine in the mixture, but it was overpowering after it cooked.  The cream cheese was also too heavy.  I think next time I will use about half as much cream cheese and add 1/4 cup or so of monterey jack.  Twelve mushrooms weren't enough, I had to use about 20 small to medium mushrooms and cook them for 25 minutes.  I will also cook these a bit longer next time or par cook the mushrooms first.  This recipe is a good good base, but needs a little work.

None
text:
This dish is awesome.  The only thing I don't like is I found the mushrooms a little too soggy.  To change this, I'd pre-baked the mushrooms in a 400F oven for about 10-15 minutes or until the water leaks out of it. Then, soak up any additional moisture with paper towels.  Stuff the mushrooms and bake the mushrooms for another 10-15 minutes.  Serve while hot.

Hope this helps :)

UNBELIEVABLE!!!!   I made these last night for my husband's birthday dinner, and he instantly started gushing over them!  The spice is perfect.

 I added some chives in the stem and garlic mixture to give some color and freshness. I also brushed mushrooms with butter and dusted with italian bread crumbs before filling and cooking. userID:
4853348
Display Name:
Annie Ross
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6844556.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wanted to make stuffed mushrooms for a party but never did like the recipe I typically made - you know, the classic one with breadcrumbs and bacon and lots of labor.  So I found this one and wondered if almost 2000 rave reviews could be wrong.  They were NOT! 

 My guests were over the moon for them.  I heard comments like:  "I NEVER eat mushrooms, but these are amazing."  The next time I saw one guest, his first question was, "How did you make those mushrooms? They were fantastic."  "Usually, stuffed mushrooms are just a lot of bread. What is in here??" (I heard that one twice.)

The only change I made from the original recipe was to add a couple of slices of day-old bread to the food processor while I was preparing the mushroom stems and garlic.  I did not bother with any other topping, as some reviewers did.  Personally, I think they are great as they are.

I prepared them the night before and put them on a baking sheet lined with parchment, which made clean-up a breeze. The next day, I put them on the bottom rack of the oven at 350 and just let them cook until the tops browned.

Thanks for a show-stopper recipe!

text:
I changed up the recipe just a little bit by adding an onion and a bell pepper to the stuffing (I just wanted to get rid of them before they go bad), and I also added a dollop of sour cream that was sitting in the fridge. I used some pretty large mushrooms, so the stuffing turned out to be just enough. I kept everything else exactly as this recipe says and the outcome was delicious!!! I didn't know I could make mushrooms like these at home! I'm going to try out some other alterations to this recipe and see how they go. Even my teenage brother who isn't a big fan of mushrooms (and anything without meat) asked for seconds!
