text:
Tried 0412/2011 - We loved them.  I only minced one clove of garlic, so I'm sure I didn't use a full teaspoon (my husband is not a big garlic fan), and while I thought they were great, the full 1/4 t. of cayenne pepper did make them seem pretty hot.  I would use the same amount again for us, but be aware of it if you're family doesn't like too much heat.  We actually had a few left over and I was worried they might not fare very well getting nuked in the microwave for today's lunch, but I thought they were fine (not quite as good as last night, but MUCH better than I was anticipating).

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I hate mushrooms- but LOVE these!  Amazing!  Wonderful!  Everyone RAVED!  My hubby couldn't be more picky - and he continues to beg for these.  I must say though, I really wanted sausage in it so I added about 1/2 pound of the regular breakfast (comes in a tube thingy) sausage. :)  I think it added to the spice of it.  I know we should try the regular recipe first... I'm a rebel.  Oh... and one time I sprinkled a little parm on top... probably not worth the extra effort to be honest.  I cooked them until the tips on top were looking brown and a hint of crunch- yummm!

~TIP~  I recommend cooking on an air fryer / cooling rack.  I used my cooling rack over a cookie sheet allowing the grease to drain away nicely the first time I did these and they were truly perfect.  The next time I was feeling lazy and just put them on a cookie sheet... they were much more soggy and greasy in a bad way (remember I used sausage too though).  I highly recommend the cooling rack & cookie sheet method.

Thanks for an excellent recipe!

These were pretty amazing - and easy! I didn't measure, and they were very forgiving. I had a bag full of mushrooms - didn't count. 1 mushroom broke, so I threw it in with the stems. I didn't have a full box of cream cheese, so I used what I had and still had more than I needed (but it didn't go to waste :D) Also found out after I started that I didn't have any garlic except powder! Used it anyways... We used the suggestion of putting it in ziploc bag and cutting off an end so as to make a pastry bag. Covered them with grated parmesan and broiled them when they were done. Delicious - I'll be making them again

text:
These were amazing! I followed the recipe exactly! I had tons of leftover filling so I stuffed fresh jalepenos and it was just as amazing! Just some tips, definitely slice a layer off the cap so the mushrooms don't roll, I also did that with the japs, and I melted butter and rolled the caps in there to keep it moist. I am a huge fan of putting the filling in a baggie and snipping off the end to pipe it in, way less mess and looks better over all. The recipe is perfect tho! Maybe ill add some chopped japs next time, or sautee onions, Idk, its already great as is.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe!  I did a few tweaks, but nothing major:  I added crumbled bacon to the cheese mixture and used green onion instead of onion powder.  I pulsed the green onion in a food processor a few times and added to the mix.  I also added white crab and tiny shrimp, and this gave the flavor more depth.  I also sprinkled the tops with bread crumbs before baking, and I dipped the mushrooms in melted butter so they wouldn't dry out.  I also baked these in a muffin tin, which worked perfectly.  I think next time I'll add less cream cheese since the filling was very thick.  Regardless, it was still great and my hubby loved them!!

None
country:
None
text:
I used 1/4 of the stuffing mix to stuff 5 large mushroom and still threw some of it away.  So feel free to plan more than 12 mushroom - maybe twice that.  I didn't have any cayenne pepper so I subbed a few drops Tabasco sauce.  My palate is boring so I thought the pepper sauce was overwhelming.  Next time will try with green tabasco.  After drying the mushrooms well, I spayed the bottoms of the mushrooms with Pam.  I topped the mushrooms with a mix made 50/50 of bread crumbs and parm cheese.  I also spritzed the tops with Pam.  Baked for 10 min and broiled for 5.  Watch to ensure the tops don't get too dark.  ty for sharing your recipes.

text:
I made these for a NEW YEARS party. They were gone instantly. Very high raves! I took care to let the mushroom caps dry before stuffing. Too like other members mentioned I added about a 1/4 cup of seasoned bread crumbs. (I used croutons). Too I did add some crab-meat. I am sure that these rock just as written. My one complaint is I only got the one mushroom that I tested. Put a few aside for yourself. Lastly there was a lot of stuffing left over... gotta figure out what to do with it!  These are absolutely a "must keep" recipe....yummy!

text:
I made these for a party last night and they were so well received, they disappeared in a flash! I followed the recipe exactly except I opted to leave out the cayenne pepper and I sprinkled some italian bread crumbs on top. It was still wonderful. I followed another reviewer's suggestion and put the cream cheese in a baggie (freezer size if you're doubling) and worked the filling ingredients in the bag, snipped the corner and used it as a pastry bag to fill the mushrooms. Worked like a charm! You may want to double this recipe because they go fast! Thank you, Angie!

text:
These are fantastic. The cayenne pepper adds the perfect punch.   I found this recipe to yield much more stuffing mixture than required for 12 mushrooms, or even 2x 8 oz. packages of medium sized baby portobello. I would plan on having 3x packages of 1.5-2.0" diameter mushrooms.   I also found that mixing everything together was much easier with rather warm, almost melted cream cheese. Then, refrigerate the mixture until firm.

I assume these must be good -- I made about 15, had 4 dinner guests, and they were all gone by the time I finished popping the entree in the oven and made it back to the living room. I have to admit that I thought this was a bizarre recipe for stuffed mushrooms, but I stand humby corrected!!!!  These are wonderful!!!!!  I made them just as the recipe called and took them to my euchre group for them to try and they ate everyone!!!! I used all of the mix as well because I had 20 mushroom caps to fill!!! text:
These were so wonderful!! Just as great if not better than anything I'd get in a restaurant. I used 1/3 less fat cream cheese, and the taste was still exquisite. Next time I will either make a lot more mushrooms and use less of the cream cheese mixture in each or scale back the cream cheese because it had a very strong cream cheese flavor. These are super delicious, but rich! I served them as a side dish with shrimp scampi, and I would not do that again! Definately should be served 30 minutes or so before a meal as an appetizer! I added about 1/2 cup of chopped crab, which was fabulous! Also took other reviewers' advice and dipped them mushroom caps in a butter and Italian breadcrumb mixture before baking. Sprinkled with grated Parmesan cheese just before going into the oven. Baked in mini muffin cups, which was perfect. The cayenne adds a wonderful "zip"! Definately will be making these again!

Excellent recipe. Like other reviewers said, I halved the cream cheese and added 2 tablespoons of bread crumbs to the mixture. Definitely a keeper recipe! Thanks!

I enjoyed these and thought that they were very good, but I thought they could have been better for a couple of reasons.  First, I took the advice to butter the outside of the mushrooms, and while this made them cook nicely, it didn't enhance the flavor of the mushroom much.  Next time, I will add some garlic and salt (or just garlic salt) to the butter to give the mushroom a little flavor.  Also, I didn't add crabmeat, but I think that it would have been much better if I had.  I will do this next time.  Overall, very good!!  I will fix these again!

text:
These were great, and a lot easier than some other stuffed mushroom recipes I've tried in the past! I skipped the cayenne and went easy on the black pepper since my son doesn't tolerate it, and they were still great. I doubled the recipe and did 24 moderate sized mushrooms (one of the really big containers) and have a ton of leftover stuffing that we'll either make another batch or use it on bagels. Also subbed Neufatchel cheese for cream cheese since it's softer but with the same taste. VERY rich!

I made this appetizer for football Saturday and my wife and son both raved about it. Both are brutally honest about my cooking, so I know they truly enjoyed it. userID:
23220
Display Name:
Tina Beer

59

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1907535.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Update to my review: Used the mandolin slicer and took one swipe across the cap of the mushroom. This made a flat surface where the mushroom won't tip over.  I also mixed the filling right in a baggie.  Just put all the ingredients straight into the bag and zipped it up and mushed it together until mixed.  Made clean up a breeze!  I put a little extra shredded parm on the top of each one too.  I made a few hours in advance and put on a cookie sheet.  I put a wire cake rack over the top of the cookie sheet which stood just about an inch over the mushrooms.  Wrapped the whole thing with wire rack and all in saran wrap and popped in the fridge so they wouldn't dry out and so the wrapping wouldn't "smush" the mushrooms.  Worked like a dream.  When I was ready to make them, just cut through the saran wrap with scissors and popped them in the oven.  Very easy.  Everyone loves these.  I've made these several times.  They're awesome.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2007-12-27T20:04:48.977
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1517023
Display Name:
JennyR
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
4
favoritesCount:
31
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674167.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I chose this recipe because it didn't contain the ubiquitous bread crumbs.  I was delighted to find that it made by far the best stuffed mushrooms I've ever had, at home or in a restaurant! I substituted minced fresh onion for the onion powder and sauteed it, with the mushroom stems and garlic, in butter.  When it cooled, I dumped it into a gallon ziploc bag with the other ingredients, kneaded them together, cut one corner off  the bag and piped it into the mushroom caps.  Popped it in the oven and presto - I am a kitchen goddess! They were so good, I felt like I needed to pretend the recipe was more difficult; my family is going to expect triumphs like this every night.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

text:
I hate to give a poor review; I know this must be a good recipe, and I know I am a good cook, but it didn't turn out well at all.  I baked them just a little over the cooking time so the tops would brown a bit and the mushrooms cooked way down and released so much liquid that it was almost like they were sitting in soup.  I also found that they did not transport well at all and as they lost heat on the buffet table, they became less and less appetizing. Kudos to everyone who enjoyed this one -- it just did not turn out well for me at all.

text:
Gorgeous.  Made these for our Christmas dinner, they were a huge hit.  My picky eater husband absolutely loved them.  Will definitely be making them again and may try them with crabmeat.  I used a plastic sandwich bag and piped the filling in and topped them with a little extra parmesan and a little sprinkle of cayenne.  Had more than enough filling for 12 mushrooms so I used the left-over filling as a dip for celery and crackers.
Very quick and easy.. definitely one for the recipe box.

text:
I followed the recipe exactly except I added a small can of minced clams and dipped the mushroom top in breadcrumbs.  I also froze mine one day before, then pulled them out and cooked them.  I was not happy with the results as I found them very watery; next time I will not freeze them and see how they turn out.  I think you could safely cut back on the cream cheese to a 6oz--my guests did not complain-they all disappeared.  I used medium size mushrooms and used 2 packages-plenty of filling plus leftover...thanks for the great recipe!

text:
I've been using this recipe for quite some time.  These are a crowd pleaser, but I can't help but think that something crunchy needs to be added.  Maybe bacon, although that would change the flavor a bit.  The mushrooms have a one-note flavor and it just makes you want something more.  However, I will say they are very good.  I have tasted these before with raw garlic (not my doing).  Don't do this!  It ruins the taste!

text:
These mushrooms are great and easy to make!  You can really add anything to this recipe and they will still turn out great.  I added a can of crabmeat and a few italian crackers.  The ziplock bag trick and dipping the mushrooms in butter works wonders!  My guests enjoyed the kick of the cayenne pepper, but if you don't like spicy food (like me), try reducing the amount of pepper or simply remove it.  Regardless, this recipe is a sure thing and you can't mess it up!  You gotta love that!

these were great at a recent party, although i'd suggest two things-- these aren't the sort of appetizers that do well if you sit them on a plate and let people eat them over a period of time-- when they cool they aren't as good. also, make sure to warn your guests that they can be messy! they are so juicy (which is good!) that a couple of my guests dripped right on their shirts. oops!

I used only half the amount cream cheese and adjusted the remaining ingredients accordingly and this filled 12 mushrooms with some leftover. city:

country:
None
text:
Don't know why, but these didn't cut it for me or my family.  Perhaps I didn't cook them long enough.  It was my first time making stuffed mushrooms, and after about 15 minutes I checked up on them and water was under the caps, so I took them out. I didn't use as much cayene as called for, which might have been why the cream cheese was overpowering. I had lots of leftover cream cheese mixture too.  But others love it, so thanks for the recipe. -----  10/23/09:  Second Time GREAT!  Last time I didn't use enough cayenne, and this time I used 3/4 of the amount.  I would stick with half.  It was far too spicy (although if cold, 75% of the cayenne is perfect).  These were tasty, easy to make, and had great presentation.  I cut a tiny slice off the rounded part so they sat flat.  Also, as another review kindly advised, put your mushroom stems into a blender to chop them up.  After the skillet stage, put the filling into a zip-lock plastic baggie, cut off an end, and use it to pipe into the mushrooms.  I had them for a dinner party and they were a hit.

text:
This is a great recipe! I just made a few changes and it came out amazing. 

I used mini-mushrooms instead of large mushrooms. I cut down on the sour cream by half (which really made a huge difference). I mixed the grated parm cheese with feta cheese and I topped the mushrooms off with crushed croutons.

I only had to cook them for a little over 10 minutes. 

I am not a fan of sour cream nor am I a fan of mushrooms normally, but all the ingredients together really makes it delicious.

text:
I just made these mushrooms tonight and my husband and I really enjoyed them.  I thought there was way too much cream cheese though.  I threw half of the mixture out because I couldn't fit it into the mushrooms.  And, of the remaining mixture, it still seemed like too much - we could barely taste the mushrooms.  Next time I will try using just 3-4 ounces of cream cheese, and cut back on the other seasons accordingly.  Ovderall, this recipe was really good though!!!  The cayenne added a great kick and we love garlic.  TIP: Blend the mixture together with your hand.  It is much easier.  Then, add it to the mushrooms using your fingers and a butter knife.  I found this was the easiest thing to do.

userID:
479071
Display Name:
KARISUENICHOLS
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
70
favoritesCount:
214
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/422872.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a really good appetizer recipe.  I used about 16 large button mushrooms. I washed & broke off the stems about 4 hours before my guests arrived.  I tossed the mushrooms in olive oil as another reviewer suggested, but I found that I was out of the lemon juice (needed for acidulation)...but the mushrooms still looked fresh and did not discolor very much after 3 1/2 hours in the fridge.  I too sprinkled the top of each mushroom with seasoned breadcrumbs.  After they were prepared, I covered them and put them in the fridge-- so I only had to stick them in the oven when my guests arrived. I gave them an extra 5 minutes in the oven because they went in straight out of the fridge and they turned out nice and hot with the breadcrumbs slightly browned.  The only thing I might do differently is to not fill them as full as I did (heaping+).  They were a little messy for my guests to pick up and eat...but there weren't any leftover, so I guess they didn't mind too much.  Very good recipe--not too difficult and they look pretty impressive.

I made these for the first time because my older sister was bothering me to make stuffed mushrooms for her. So I ended up making them for my mother's birthday dinner and I hoped for the best. I wanted the best and I got the best because they were SO GOOD!! I personally hate mushrooms and even I can't keep my hands off of these! One thing I changed though. Perfect appatizers for a party, or if you just want something easy to show-off with. ^____^ Thank you, Angie!

text:
Very good! And it does make alot. I took the warning and bought extra mushrooms. It filled 2lbs of assorted sized caps. The only thing I changed was that I added Hormel bacon bits (the real stuff) because I was out of parmesan cheese. I used maybe 2-3 tablespoons of the bacon pieces and it was excellent. It might also be an answer to some of the reviewers who felt that this was just to "bland" or "cream cheesy". It gave it an added dimension in both taste and texture. Everyone wanted this recipe! Thanks!

text:
I really liked this recipe.  I did however made a few changes that made
them even better.  I finely chopped up portabello mushrooms instead of the 
stems of the regular mushrooms and also added finely chopped cooked turkey
bacon and chives and topped them off with breadcrumbs.  The breadcrumbs add a crunchy 
texture to the soft cheese mixture.  I have made them this way on several 
occasions and they always disappear quickly!

text:
I have made these stuffed mushrooms many times from I recipe I found in a Junior-League cookbook. This is a wonderful recipe requested frequently by my teenage son. My recipe also calls for the addition of 1/4 to 1/3 cup of crumbled crisp bacon  mixed into the cream cheese mixture and topped with a sprinkling of shredded cheddar cheese. Great!

These were absolutely scrumptious! I made them for Thanksgiving, and while I make stuffed mushrooms every year, I have never seen any disappear so fast. Very savory, very unique. My only suggestion is to add a lot of salt, and a bit less cream cheese. Also, easy on the cayenne! I gave the recipe to two family members and my husband said it was a "keeper."

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4569544.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe several times. It is excellent as is. The last time I tried it, I decided to replace the garlic for shallots, added fresh thyme and a splash of Sherry wine to the stems. Needless to say my guest raved about them. Both the hubby and I were in love with them even though we have eaten them many times. This   slight modification made them even better and gave them a slight twist in flavor for variation. I sprinkled a bit of bread crumbs on top for decoration and popped them in the oven. They were delicious. Try them both ways, you will not regret it! I made 12 white mushrooms and did not use the full 8 oz. of cream cheese. I used about 5 oz. and that was enough for my mushroom caps, so be mindful and either use less cream cheese or use it all and add a few more mushroom caps.

Mountain Gal

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were wonderful BUT I don't know if I will make them again.  They are surprisingly tedious and time-consuming to make (in my limited culinary opinion).  I made them for my book group holiday party and they were gone IN AN INSTANT which speaks to how delicious they are.  I am not in anyway criticizing the recipe, just my cooking/prep time expectations.

My filling was comprised of  the sautéed garlic and chopped "mushroom guts", 1/4 cup panko crumbs, 1/4cup shredded parmesan, 1 8-ounce package of cream cheese, and the seasonings per the recipe.  I put  small amount of prosciutto in the bottoms of the mushroom caps before squeezing the filling on top.  Unsure if I would use prosciutto again, as it was more work, more cost, and I didn't really notice the taste.  I made about 30 small-medium mushrooms with this and still had enough left-over filling to probably do about 15 more (fun fact:  the left-over filling is delicious on a toasted bagel the next morning!)  Put a little more shredded parm cheese on top before baking, and there you have it.

My family loved it, I wasn't too impressed.  I used real Parmesan, not the kind you buy for pizza.  The Parmesan was too strong for my taste.  Maybe I should have used the kind of parmesan that you shake out of a container.  If using real paremesan, may want to hold off how much you put in this recipe. country:
None
text:
Use bite size smaller mushrooms to make it easier to eat as a appetizer and double them. Olive oil instead of vegetable oil.  Add to the original ingredients for the filling: 2 stalks green onions (minced and cooked with the garlic and mushroom stems), a bit more parmesan, garlic powder, crisp bacon and about a cup of cooked dungeoness crab. Dunk the caps in melted butter & lemon before filling, sprinkle with more parmesan and bake in a mini muffin pan. (Beware: if the mushrooms don't fit all the way into the muffin pan, they will come out shaped like muffins! It is kind of cute though.) Cooked for 20 mins. The parmesan topping gives it that extra crunch. Love the heat the Cayenne leaves after you eat it.

Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-03-17T19:20:18.047

text:
Grab em fast or you won't get any!!

I added 3 scallions, few drops of worcestershire, 2 tbsp of panko bread crumbs, a few pieces of bacon chopped very fine, and a dab of butter.

I painted on butter to the shroom caps so they would stay moist, filled, topped with morqe panko, finished with a heavy spinkle of parm.

Baked at 350 for 20 mins and finished with 5 mins of briol or until tops are golden. Yum!!!!

With these mods I'd rate them a 5/5

text:
Yum! This is my first time making them and bringing to a family gathering as a side. It was hard to gauge as I made 40 mushrooms (But they were mixed types and some were tiny). Used romano instead of parmesan for the mixture and doubled the recipe, but only ended up using about 3/4 of it. Added the green onion as others did and topped with breadcrumbs and grated parmesan. I said ' I think I'll make these again' and my husband (who was a huge help in prep) said, 'oh, you're definitely making these again!' So it was a win!
*Made these a 2nd time using Vegan cream cheese and added real goat cheese crumbles to the mix for flavor for an overall less calorie, lactose friendly option. Still fabulous!

text:
I’ve wanted to try making stuffed mushrooms for a while, and these turned out really well. It was a little time consuming, but not difficult. I added a little more garlic and cayenne than called for, doubled the mushrooms, and topped with a mixture of breadcrumbs and shredded parmesan per other reviewers’ advice. The only change I would make would be to add a little chopped bacon or Italian sausage to the filling, just to give it more texture, it was a little too creamy. That said, they only lasted about ten minutes, I would definitely make them again.

userID:
23711960
Display Name:
Hope Alvarado
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5395153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe almost exactly and they were really delicious. But I did have plenty of extra filling that I ate with some crackers. 

Don't preheat your oven right away. The chopping can be time consuming if you don't use some kind of appliance other than a knife, but the thing is, that the filling needs to cool before you even fill the mushrooms. I wouldn't preheat the oven until you've taken the filling off the stove. 

 I didn't see any reason to wait for the mixture to cool before putting in the spices and parmesan cheese. It's easier to mix evenly while the ingredients are warm.

My oven is new so it runs hotter then I'm used to, and I still thought they could have cooked another minute or two.

I would either double the number of mushrooms or cut the amount of cream cheese in half. 

I picked this recipe because it's low-carb-- no bread crumbs. However, I think a sprinkle of panko bread crumbs on top would make them even better. I want to try mixing in some chunk crab meat, next time. They seem to need a little texture as the stuffing is very creamy and the mushrooms are soft.
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2018-04-28T19:49:49.003
helpfulCount:
0

text:
This was the first time ever making stuffed anything.  It was an easy recipe to follow...and simple.  I read the other reviews and I did change a couple of things.  I used olive oil and I added more fresh grated parmesan to the filling.  I also sauteed finely diced onion with the garlic and stems.  Last, I topped each mushroom with a small bit of mozzarella and melted it in the oven (broil).  You really can taste each ingredient and I think they taste just as good the day after as leftovers.

It was delicious! However I'd make some changes. I'd put the filling in a ziploc bag, and cut the bottom corner out to use as a pipette to fill the mushroom caps more easily. Also I'd cut in half all the ingredients except the mushrooms themselves because I had way too much filling. I'd also put on the Parmesan cheese at the end instead of in the filling for that extra crunch. But overall, the cayenne pepper added a nice little kick to it that went very well with it. A delicious recipe!

text:
This recipe was a hit, and the mushrooms were gone it no time!  I didn't have grated Parmesan cheese, so used a cheddar blend in place of it.  I also added about 4 ounces already cooked hot ground sausage to the cream cheese mixture.  I used a 1-pound package of small mushrooms, and had about 25% of the filling left over.  The next time I make them, I will buy larger mushrooms, so there is more room for the filling.  I made these to serve that evening, but then forgot all about cooking them.  I kept them refrigerated, then baked and served them the following night.  I don't think this hurt them in any way.  I like being able to prep foods ahead of time, so was glad to see that it works for this recipe.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ugh, there were horrific. 20 minutes at 350 degrees makes a slimy rubbery ball of mushroom cap with no flavor except the cheese that's dripped everywhere but. 

No, to make this combination of ingredients edible I had to chop the stuffed mushrooms and stick in a pan with a little olive oil and fry it all, cheese as well, because this is not a normal flavor combination, and then add some toasted bread "croutons" in order for it to have some actual food to cling to. Now, it's been hours and there's still an aftertaste. I'm am so done with mushrooms after yet another failure.

Other recipes for stuffed mushrooms advise baking or roasting the empty caps thoroughly for 20 minutes on one side, the flipping and giving it another 10 minutes, then filling and then baking again for 10 minutes, all at 450 degrees!

Also, there's nothing in the recipe regarding a parmesan or bread crumb topping, though something is shown in the original and other folks' photos.

None
text:
This is easy enough to make that it doesn't need to be saved for parties. You do need more then 12 mushrooms for the 8 oz cream cheese, and I added some garlic powder and extra parm. The mushroom stems really cook down, so maybe I'd add in an extra mushroom next time. Really tasty! Edit: if you use fresh ground black pepper, it gives it a bit of zip, and you could scale back if your crowd isn't into that.

text:
This is a different type stuffed mushroom dish.  We liked it, and might make them again.  One thing you might want to do before making any stuffed mushroom, is to remove the lungs.  Do this by gently scooping it out with a spoon.   You will be able to add more stuffing to the mushroom.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
replaced: vegetable oil with equal Olive oil.  Parmesan with equal shredded mozzarella.  400F instead of 350F
deviations: I drained the excess oil from the mushroom and garlic bits before mixing.

Absolutely what I was hoping for.  I popped one of them in my mouth after they cooled, and it was... really, really hard not to eat the rest...

Suggestion for others: Make sure you have BIG mushrooms.  Some of mine were barely more than an inch across, and they couldn't actually fit much of the cream cheese mix in them.   I had left over cream cheese mix, too.  The few I had that were ~2 inches in diameter were just about right.

Just made this exactly to spec. Way too hot for my family!!! I will probably do 1/2 the amt of Cayenne pepper and black pepper next time. I personally like stuff with a kick. These are still burning my lips and throat. My nose is runny too. Lol

I did like 1 review to coat the shrooms with melted butter. I also enjoyed dipping my shroom in fresh squeezed lemon juice. I may cut the cream cheese in 1/2 next time and replace with Italian bread crumbs to lighten the taste. Overall, a great flavor!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a half recipe.  Skipped the onion powder, but added 1 green onion to the saute mix.   After cooling, added some cooked breakfast sausage and mixed all with the cream cheese.  After stuffing, mounding with a spoon, topped with  2 Tbs. Italian bread crumbs mixed with 2 Tbs. mellted butter,  2 Tbs. grated and chopped Parmasan, and a pinch of grated lemon zest. and baked.  Tasty, and will make again.  6/24/17:  Made again today making a whole recipe instead of half and added 1/3 c. chopped bacon.  Yum!  However, a half recipe is more than enough for 8 oz. of mushrooms.  Spread the rest of the filling on crackers to eat.  Tried baking in a mini-muffin pan but did not like the results.  Although they were a perfect fit in the pan, they came out mushy because there was nowhere for the moisture to escape.  Next time will go back to using a glass casserole dish.  It prevents the mushrooms from rolling off the sides (like on a cookie sheet) and allows enough space between the mushrooms for them to cook without becoming mushy.

userID:

Display Name:
schmoop
isPro:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were very good for the first go around.  I will admit I read a bunch of reviews and borrowed ideas that I thought were helpful, so I apologize it isn't exactly as the recipe is written.  

The only ingredient I added was about a cup of crabmeat.  I went a little heavy - heaping 1/4 teaspoon of cayenne and used about a half cup of fresh shredded parm.  I didn't have onion powder so I used about a tablespoon of dried chopped onion in its place and sautéd with stems and garlic.  I did dunk the shrooms in melted butter prior to filling to help keep them moist while cooking.  Using a zip lock bag to fill them was really a big help as well.  

Lastly I topped each one with a good amount of Italian seasoned breadcrumbs and drizzled the rest of the butter over that.  Cooked for 20 minutes and broiled for the last 5-8 for a crunchy brown top.   

I really didn't think 1/4 tsp. of cayenne could be too powerful for the amount of cream cheese etc, which is why I went a little heavy, but they did have more bite than I expected. So that is something to consider depending on your tastes.  I was surprised my husband liked them as much as he did because he isn't a big fan of too much spice which is up my alley.  He said he liked the after kick and not to use less next time.  And there will be a next time.  Will also play around with adding some other options. like bacon, had I had some on hand last time would have added - there are a bunch of ideas.  

Reheating the leftovers day two wa

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Due to the mixed reviews on this recipe as-is,  I first put together the filling as written and stuffed one mushroom, as a "test" subject. The original recipe is fine, if a little boring. As it stood, I ended up doubling the recipe, and added about 1/4t of garlic powder, some chopped green onions, and about a pound of shrimp (they were on sale and way less expensive than crab, but still added that extra something). 

I made these the night before, then right before serving I pulsed together a couple plain rice cakes, some shredded Romano cheese, and some more green onions, topped the shrooms, and baked accordingly. With those changes, this recipe is definitely a keeper!

text:
I made this but i sautéed the mushrooms in butter and minced garlic first before baking in the oven @425 for 20 min.   Secondly.... I made the filling but added some shredded artisan Chedder cheese and sun-dried tomatoes in olive oil (tbsp or more of olive oil also with sun-dried tomatoes) xtra cayenne, freshly ground cracked pepper and NO SALT..... (per parm is salty already) . Thirdly....i put xtra shredded cheese and parsly panko mixture on top. It gives a great texture/crunch factor!!!  Then drizzled melted butter over each one.

We loved this version of the recipe. It was creamy, cheesey, hint of spicy and full  flavor with the sun dries tomatoes in olive oil.  Will continue to make this  years to come!!! So delicious.

text:
I followed the directions and first I've got to say that cheese stuffing is divine! I could eat it with a spoon! It would be great on baked potatoes, too. When I make it again I think I will use portobello mushrooms since they have a large flat fillable surface. I had difficulty with the mushrooms I chose. They were rounded and wanted to roll on the cookie sheet. I lost a lot of filling goodness that melted on the cookie sheet. Although the stem hole was deep, it wasn't wide enough to hold the cheesy goodness. But this recipe is definitely a winner, if just for the cheese filling alone!

This is great on bagels, or you can do what I usually do and just double the mushrooms.

text:
Unfortunately these didn't live up to my expectations. First off, an incorrect picture is shown on the recipe page. This recipe does not use any breadcrumbs, but that's clearly what we see in the picture. Secondly, 8 ounces is way too much cream cheese! It's an entire block! It overpowers the flavor. With no breadcrumbs, the filling texture is left to be desired. Also, oil is not needed to remove water from chopped mushrooms; simply put the finely chopped mushrooms into a skillet on medium heat. Saute the garlic separately! I'm just disappointed. :(

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I started with the original recipe and kept notes handy from previous reviews, tasting as I went. It was definitely too rich and not at all "stuffing" like. I added 1/2 c. panko bread crumbs, 1/4 parm, and ground smoked chipotle instead of the spicier pepper. I minced the stems and sautéed them with 6 cloves of fresh garlic in olive oil and a tiny bit of truffle oil. The entire volume when combined filled 10 medium portobello mushroom caps (~2-3" across). 

The flavor was decent. Very creamy still but better with the panko (more like a stuffing). My vegetarian friend enjoyed them and had seconds! ???? Would I make them again? Probably not. They were underwhelming.

text:
My husband loves stuffed mushrooms so I made these for him.  He raved about them!  After eating a few we settled on a few things.  There was too much cream cheese, it could have used some sausage or bacon maybe for added flavor.  I did dip the mushrooms in butter before the oven to keep them from drying out and also a splash of worchestershire sauce to the sautee mix.  A very good recipe - but may change those things next time.

userID:
17944469
Display Name:
Cookaroo
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3529597.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Thanks to all of the reviews to helping me tweek the recipe! I put in olive oil instead of vegetable oil to make the mushroom stem mixture, but did not bake mushrooms in oil because it is healthier without it. Got rid of the onion powder all together, but added some lemon in the filling. Added a bit less cayenne pepper, and it was still a still a little too spicy for my liking. Put in only half of the cream cheese package, and sprinkled parsley on top after it was cooked. I love how this recipe includes using mushroom stems, I think that it was much less wasteful that way.  I used a mini cupcake tin for baking. If you only have a regular-sized muffin tin, cover it in foil and finger-press the groves to fit the size of the mushrooms. I used the ziplock piping bag trick, and it worked perfectly. Half of my mushrooms I coated in italian breadcrumbs, the other half with parmesan. If you like bagel bites, coat the mushrooms with cheese! If you like a more resteraunt-style dish, coat it with breadcrumbs! Disclaimer: Breadcrumbs will come out soggy if you don't put enough on! Here is my complaints: The flavors didn't blend as well as I had hoped.  Some other friends thought it wasn't half bad. This recipe can appeal to many, but many don't like it at all. It's kind of a 50/50 thing. I would say give it a shot, but cut the recipe in half if you are making it for the first time to test it out. The recipe makes A LOT

text:
I love this recipe, as is and/or with a few of the suggestions other reviewers have made. I always use more mushrooms because it makes a lot of filling. When I want to get fancy I will brush the shrooms with butter and roll the tops in breadcrumbs before baking. When I want meat, I add a yummy ground sausage. When I want healthy, I cut the cream cheese down to 1/3 and add 1/2 cup quinoa...delicious and less guilty. It has the right amount of heat with the seasoning, and is always the first plate to disappear at a party. Thanks for the recipe! I have used it for years and will for years to come.

text:
I've made these several times and changed up the recipe different ways. I have added hot sausage to the  mix and let that cook with the stems.

I have also added chopped shrimp (raw) to the mix and let that cook in the oven.  

I almost always add chopped chives, or sweet onions to the mix for a very full flavor. This is a great base recipe to build your taste preferences on.

text:
Used small (8oz) pkg mushrooms. Chopped all stems but halved rest of recipe. (Had perfect amount for 12 mushrooms). Halved garlic, oil, onion powder, parm cheese and cream cheese. Didn't use hot spice.  Mixed in ziploc. Piped mixture in as suggested. Buttered bottom of Corning dish. Sprinkled tiny bit of plain Panco breadcrumbs over top. Added about 3T Marsala wine to bottom of dish. Baked at 350 for 15 mins and 375 for 15 mins more.

text:
Fabulous - as voted by all party guests!  Only changes made in ingredients was to reduce amount of cream cheese by 1/3 and to use tops of green onions chopped and added raw directly to cream cheese mixture.  The cream cheese mixture was made two hours in advance of stuffing & baking, left at room temperature, then easily stuffed delicate mushroom cavities, without breakage.  Will definitely used this as my go-to appetizer in future entertaining.

I used Neufchâtel cheese, (often called 1/3rd less fat cream cheese).  I chose to have it a bit less spicy with 1/8th teaspoon black pepper and 1/8th teaspoon cayenne pepper.  Baked for 30-35 minutes,  until I saw the liquid stopped forming under the the caps.  My first batch was too juicy to serve, IMO.

text:
The good news is that if you skip the part where you sauté the mushrooms & garlic, and just stuff it and bake it still turns out ok! I had made this once before,  months ago and in a mad hurry to get dinner done, I skipped the step. Woops. Still good tho, don't fret if it happens to you. I didn't have cream cheese but sour cream and still delish. Will make this again for sure & I won't worry if I forget to sauté.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed this recipe exactly as written except I didn't have 12 large mushrooms, so I used 2 8oz. containers of just regular white mushrooms. That was a perfect amount! Using 1/4 tsp of cayenne gave it more of a kick than I am used to, still really good, never had a stuffed mushroom with a kick, the hubby and I thought we could do it with maybe 1/8 tsp next time. I took an equal amount of Progresso Garlic & Herb bread crumbs and plain Panko and mixed them together and before I put the mushrooms in the oven I took each cap and dipped the tops in the breadcrumbs. Perfect crunch and flavor on top! Will definitely make this again!

text:
The recipe was okay. The cream cheese mix (which I added cilantro to) tasted really good. It would have been a great spread for crackers. I wish, however, that there were more filling and less cream cheese. It was a bit too creamy. I also added bread crumbs to the top of the mushrooms and it added a lovely level of crispiness!

Definitely give this recipe a try, but use a bit less cream cheese and a bit more filling. Find something fun and creative to add to the recipe to give it flavor!

text:
Pretty good. I used 1 lb of baby bellas and only used half the filling. (Even so, I thought there was WAY too much filling in the mushrooms.) If I made them again, I would only make half or a third the amount of filling, and definitely wouldn't fill them very full. I normally love garlic, but 1 Tbsp was too much - they were very garlicky. I would recommend only using 1-2 cloves. I will probably try another recipe next time.

Loved these. Based on recommendations, I used 2/3 of the cream cheese and added three strips of previously cooked crumbled bacon. text:
These are amazing! I made 8 (fairly large) portabella mushrooms, and found the amount of cream cheese to be very excessive. I only used 1/4 of the package, and probably could have gotten away with using even less. I added 3 tbsp of chopped fresh spinach and 1 tbsp of minced yellow onion to the mushroom/garlic mixture while it was cooking. I left the heat on very low while I stirred in the cream cheese to make it easier to mix. This is a great recipe and very versatile! Thanks.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I printed this out and doubled the recipe as some had suggested, and bought spinach as others had said.  Didn't see it mentioned anywhere what a pain it is to get out and dice up mushroom stems.  My husband ended up doing the last 12 of them for me.  And we were not making tiny pieces.  We were just dicing. We definitely did not have to double the 10 oz. of spinach or the 8 oz of cream cheese. We stopped before we put in the 2nd cream cheese and 1/2'd the mushroom stems, garlic, parmesan cheese, and spinach mixture before we filled the mushrooms.  Needless to say I have some spinach, mushroom stem, garlic mixture to give him for dinner some night.
I have learned my lesson and I will be reading recipes much more diligently from now on.  And I will, God-willing, never make this recipe again.

text:
WOW! Made these tonight for a Christmas gathering, sure the prep takes a bit but well worth it. I took some bits of info from other reviews and I ended with 55 small ( not button) mushrooms and still have filling left over. I added bacon to the garlic/stem mix, did what some said and put the garlic, cream cheese, parm all in a ziplock and mashed together that way. Less mess! Also did half with the butter/lemon dip before you fill and what a difference that makes for eye appeal. DO the butter/lemon dip its makes them look so much better. Everyone loved them! Thanks for a great appetizer!

I did add some gorgonzola crumbles for a twist. Yum. Also this mixture with some added chopped artichoke hearts will make a nice hot cheese dip!! Yum!! Next time. I will be adding this recipe to my recipe box for future events! Thank You!!!

text:
I've made these several times and everyone loves them. I always make 20/25 mushrooms and only use half cream cheese package and I add bacon to the mixture. I top mushrooms with a mix of panko and the parmesan cheese that the recipe calls for, and brush a little melted butter on top (it keeps them from drying up). 
Lastly place them on the mini muffin pan previously sprayed with cooking spray.  
Negative: A little time consuming so clean mushrooms and prepare stuffing a day or 2 before you need it.

text:
I made these for the first time for a surprise party I was hosting.  Looking at past reviews I did add crab meat and sprinked top with shredded Parm cheese.  I even cooked stems in half Olive oil and half butter for more flavor.   The reviews were "to die for" and "I haven't had these since I ate at (restuarant)" .    I am making them today for my daughters family birthday party tomorrow and love the convenience of being able to make them ahead of time and pop them in the oven before everyone arrives!   Easy, quick and a variety of possibilities to change the flavor by adding different ingredients such as crab, sausage, bacon, ham, etc.   Thank you so much for posting this recipe, it will be a staple at all my parties!

I am not a mushroom eater but I tried to find a recipe to make stuffed mushrooms from my sister-in-law and husband who loved them. I did a simple google search and it brought me to this recipe. The only thing I did that the recipe did not say was sprinkle more parmesan cheese on top before putting it in the oven and then I broiled them for a few minutes to give them a little bit of color. Great recipe!

Discovered this recipe several years ago and now this is my go to for stuffed mushrooms. We eat them pretty regularly. People always compliment me on how good they are. city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely delectable and gobbled up in minutes!  I was able to fill about 24 Baby Belle mushrooms (large and small caps) with the mix and still had about a 1/4 cup left over.  I substituted olive oil for the vegetable oil, only added in 1/8 tsp cayenne pepper and added in about a 1/2 cup of finely chopped onions and about 3/4 cup finely chopped cooked bacon.  Oh, let me say the bacon adds a DIVINE flavor that really went well with the cheese.  Next time I intend to do the same changes I referenced above but will also sprinkle them with Parmesan cheese when the cooking time is done, put them back in under the broiler for about 5 minutes and they should taste even better!

userID:
611176
Display Name:
WALTDOUD
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made these per the recipe, with the minor exception that I used some finely chopped sweet onion instead of the onion powder, which I sauteed with the garlic.  I also wrapped each one with a half of a strip of bacon that I partially microwaved to remove some of the grease and give it a "head start".  My choice of mushroom was criminy.  They were EXCELLENT!!!  The only thing I will do differently next time is to either use a thicker cut of bacon, or use the whole strip on each one.  Oh and for 20 mushrooms, an 8 oz package of cream cheese made at least twice as much filling as I needed.  So I might try to scale that back to using a 4 ounce package next time.  But overall, a great recipe!  As others mentioned, do yourself a huge favor and get your Parmesan from the gourmet cheese section of the supermarket and grate it yourself.  The stuff in the green can is OK in a pinch or for convenience for spaghetti and pizza, but your recipes will definitely come out better with freshly grated Parmesan.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
A friend of mine requested that I make something as an appetizer for her stag and doe baby shower.  I didn't want to make the usual spinach dip, so I started searching through Allrecipes.com.  This recipe was such a hit!  After reading the instructions, I thought they would be more difficult than they were.  I did add Parmesan cheese to the top as one person had suggested (shredded) and bake them.  I had to bake about 4 hours before they were served and we simple put them back in the over for another 10 minutes and it did not impede the taste.  Thanks for an amazing recipe!

I used the cream cheese and parmesan cheese and added finely chopped onion and garlic, chopped prosciutto, some ground up herbed croutons (or stuffing) and sauteed mushroom stalks.  I mixed it all together in a baggy and then cut the end off to fill the caps.  I topped it all of with a dallop of butter and slid them in the oven at 350.  Baked about 20 minutes.  I used the larger sized caps and made six of them!  They were delicious!  Yum!

country:
None
text:
These were a hit at my last party - very tasty and vegetarian friendly. I kept mine warm in the crockpot on low, but be warned you will have to drain the water out occasionally. These guys give off a lot of juice. If you have a large enough crock pot, you could put a cookie-cooling rack in the bottom, then put the mushrooms on top to avoid them drowning. Otherwise, good straight from the oven or even room temp.

text:
Being the day before Thanksgiving, we opted making this recipe with some healthier substitutions!!  Instead of using cream cheese, use a dollop or two of daisy with 2 TBSP's of Italian breadcrumbs after the mushroom mixture cools. Also did not use minced garlic and used a tablespoon of garlic powder!  Great flexible mushroom recipe!

text:
Yum! This was a big hit. Followed the recipe, but added roasted red pepper (I had used it in a previous mushroom recipe and it was delicious). I ended up with TONS of leftover filling, though, so next time will double the amount of mushrooms. I totally agree with other reviewers - keep your mushrooms on the small side (1" - 1 1/4" diameter), this helps to get the right ratio between mushroom and filling.

Easy recipe and delicious, however...I used half the cayenne and it was plenty hot enough.  Also, you need bread crumbs on top to make it a little crispy!!  Finally, we used only 1/5th the cream cheese and it was fine!!  Don't waste 8 oz of cream cheese, it might overpower everything else.

text:
I love, love, love this recipe!!   I have only given it 4 stars because the given quantity of ingredients for the filling results in way too much left-overs.    To make 12 mushrooms, i diced only 6 of the stems, and then used 1/4 of the remaining ingredients.   This made the perfect amount of filling for 12.   I also sprinkled the tops with freshly grated parmesan cheese for the last couple minutes of baking.   Will make again and again!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
These were outstanding! I followed the recipe for half (I doubled the recipe) and added smoked cheddar to the bottom of one half; my family and I couldn't even tell which had the cheddar and which didn't so I'll probably skip it next time. Oh, I did dip each mushroom in butter before baking because after reading reviews, I was afraid that they would dry up. (I doubt that they would)  I haven't had stuffed mushrooms in about twenty years because most places sell them with bacon; I was a little skeptical to try them but I ABSOLUTELY loved them! (Not a mushroom fan but I want to add more and new tastes to my palette.) These were so good that I can hardly wait to make them again! And my picky, picky kids loved them as well!  My husband suggests using white wine on the bottom of the pan while baking but since I didn't have any on hand I said I would try it next time. I loved them as is but will try them with the white wine next time and post here on how it turns out. Thanks for a great recipe!!


Quick Edit: I tried the wine the next time (a local Hawaiian Pineapple white wine) and the mushrooms did not absorb any of the liquid so I will suggest not using it but instead serving some wine along with the mushrooms. :)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I was making these for a small get-together and due to grocery-goer error (my father) I somehow ended up with a package of large portobello mushrooms and a package of sliced white mushrooms. Since it was a small get-together, I improvised and minced about 1/2 of the mushroom slices along with the stems of the portobellos and mixed as per the directions and stuffed the portobello caps, which made the filling the perfect amount. I then topped with italian style bread crumbs and some melted butter and cooked for about 30 minutes. Then I cut them into fourths and served them that way. I would lessen the cayenne in the future, though that's just personal preference. I'll definitely be making these again, though with mini portobello caps, but keep the amount of minced mushroom the same as I liked the bulk and flavour of them in the mix.

I use herb and garlic cream cheese and a can of crab.  My husband absolutely loves these and is satisfied to eat just them for his supper!  The other reviewers are correct in that there is lots of the filling left over after filling the 12 mushrooms caps.  I might try it  next time with 2/3 or just 1/2 of the cream cheese.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
With a few modifications, these are some of the best stuffed mushrooms I've eaten. I added a small (6 oz) can of minced clams (drained well) and 2 TBSP butter to the stems and garlic when browning. I also subbed out 4 oz of cream cheese and 4 oz goat cheese. I increased the garlic by 1/2 and went light on the cayenne. I used a Parmesan/Romano blend because that's what I had handy. Delicious! Tip: Cook stuffed mushrooms in a muffin pan to keep them sitting up straight. :)

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After trying the original recipe and taking a look at some of the other reviews on here, I would DEFINITELY go with 2/3 or 1/2 the amount of cream cheese, OR smaller mushrooms.   The cream cheese can just be overwhelming in (lack of) taste and texture if you go with the original. I would also at least double the amount of parmesan, and pop some worchestershire in with the garlic and spice mix to get those two flavors going.  This is a great recipe if you have a balance of flavors, but as I mentioned before, the cream cheese is just overwhelming (not to mention a little hard to clean up after if you melt or whip it)!

text:
A really good mushroom recipe for friends who don't like seafood (although you could easily stir in crabmeat for those who do).  I added finely chopped onion (equal to the amount of mushroom stems) and about 2 Tablespoons seasoned breadcrumbs.  Also thought it needed some additional seasoning, so I sprinkled in salt and garlic salt.  Very good --have made it several times over the holidays and everyone really enjoyed them.

text:
These mushrooms are simply the best. If you want to cut down on a bunch of time and a bunch of ingredients, steps, cost, cook together a tube of Jimmy Dean ground sausage (remove fat) and an 8 oz pack of cream cheese and stuff mushrooms. Stick in oven 350 for 10 min. Just as good but less steps. For attractiveness, sprinkle with a little parsley.

text:
This is a great recipe. I added a can of crab meat to the cream cheese mixture. Had to ommit the onion powder as I didn't have any on hand. These tasted amazing I dare say better then resturant quality and so easy to make!****

***I have made these several times and still love the recipe as written however, I do try and watch my diet so have since started making them with fat free cream cheese and green onions.  When I am cooking the mushroom stems I throw in the whites of the green oinons and a clove of garlic. After mixing that mixture with the cream cheese I add a can of crab and the tops of the green onions. I only use 1 maybe 2 tbls. of cheese.

This was my first attempt at stuffed mushrooms (new to cooking). Easy to follow, tasted great. We had a few left over and my wife was warming them in the microwave while I was grilling. text:
This is an outstanding appetizer!!  Definitely be sure to wipe the mushrooms clean with a damp cloth (or buy them already clean) because submersing them in water will give you really gross, soggy mushrooms when they come out of the oven.  To make it more of a side dish, I've used the extra large portobello mushrooms instead.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
These are a little more work than the stuffed mushrooms I have done in the past, but they were well worth it.  I used one regular size container of whole mushrooms that were just average size and ended up with a ton of the stuffing mixture left.  Put it in the fridge and next day stuffed another container of mushrooms that we had in the fridge.  Only comment is to make sure the mushrooms are very fresh and haven't been in the fridge for several days, as our second container had been.  The fresh mushrooms held up better to the heat and kept their shape better. Wonderful flavor!

text:
Delicious! Easier to make than I would have thought. I took the advice of others and added crumbled bacon one time, and ground sausage another to balance out the strong creamy flavor. Great idea. Though both were good, I preferred the sausage, my b/f liked the bacon. Also used romano instead of parmesan as that's what i have in my fridge and actually prefer. Also topped the mushrooms with a blend of bread crumbs and romano. I personally like the little bit of crunch to again, offset the strong taste.

text:
I made this for New Year's Eve, and it was a big hit!  I used around 45 small mushrooms, which used up all the stuffing.  
I added marinated artichoke hearts and only a small pinch of cayenne pepper. The marinated artichoke hearts created created the perfect mix of flavors.  I put a little bit of breadcrumbs in each mushroom and also dipped the mushroom tops in melted butter before baking.
Delish!

text:
Always a hit at parties! I use neufchatel (light) cream cheese to lighten a bit. I cook 3 slices of bacon and chop them up to add to the filling then sautee the garlic and mushroom in the bacon drippings rather than in oil. Don't leave out the cayenne pepper. It gives it a little zing - not enough to be spicy but just gives it something extra.

text:
I have used this particular recipe for over 5 years now and it's always a crowd pleaser. Be patient as the moisture cooks from the chopped stems and they are also great if you add some sausage to the mixture. I brown the sausage then add it once the liquid has evaporated. The sausage seems to cut the sharpness of the cream cheese. They are delicious either way!

These are foolproof!  I'm always asked for the recipe, and there are NEVER any left over.  You end up with more filling than you need for a dozen mushrooms, so I always make extra.  I guess the alternative would be to cut back on the cream cheese, but who wants to end up with ONLY twelve of these?  They're very good--very addictive.   Another bonus:  I made them once for a brunch with friends and my vegetarian friend was very grateful to find these on the table.

userID:
2816170
Display Name:
Fran
isPro:
False
followersCount:

4

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The very best stuffed mushrooms I have ever made and my sons in law ask for them a lot! 

I add a little green onion tops snipped with scissors and a bit of salt to the garlic and chopped stems. Also crush herb stuffing mix (I use my mini prep food processer) and top the stuffed mushrooms with it. Following another reviewers tip, I put a little white wine in the pan along with chicken broth (if I have a box open in the fridge) Keeps the mushrooms very moist.  Don't try to use fresh onion as it makes the mix runny.  I also make the stuffing mix ahead of time and refrigerate and it's easy to stuff the caps and firm enough to just dip in the herb dressing crumbs.
Review:

5

text:
Excellent! I added a tad too much cayenne pepper, but doing gave it that extra kick. I also halved the cream cheese amount; somehow adding 8 oz (an entire package) of cream cheese sounded too decadent. I also sliced a sliver off the top of the mushrooms to help keep them upright while I baked them. I also followed one reviewer's advice and bought smaller whole white mushrooms (used all 12 of them) which made this a bite-sized treat. Great, great recipe!

text:
Brought these to a party this weekend and everyone loved them. The only change I made was that I minced a small onion in place of the onion powder. They cayenne was the perfect amount of kick. They produced alot of juice, so half way through cooking I drained the tray so they didnt get too soggy. 
Stuffed mushrooms are alot of work, but after cleaning them out (which you have to do with any stuffed mushroom recipe) the rest of the recipe is pretty easy.

text:
This recipe is so delicious! I've made it a couple times now. I added minced green onions the second time and they were that much better - we love onions. I did two things that other reviewers suggested. I sliced a little off the top of the mushrooms to help them stand still, and then added that part of the mushroom to the filling. I also topped the mushrooms with Italian breadcrumbs, which was the final touch that took these mushrooms from great to fantastic.

I love garlic and usually will put more tha called for in a recipe.  This was the first time I tried these and I think I will actually cut the amount of garlic I use next time.  I also wasn't crazy about the texture of the cheese mixture...it seemed a bit "loose" when they came out of the oven and were not easy to eat as a "finger food", they needed a fork.  I will try this again but may add crab as some have suggested and will definately cut the amount of garlic. Maybe I used a really hot clove, but it was too much!

country:
None
text:
Be warned. As another reviewer suggested; once you take these to a party or family function - you will then be required to make them for ALL future events. Lol. These were just awesome. The only thing I added was one finely chopped green onion while sauteing. 
I had four packages of the freshest mushrooms I've seen and I still had left over filling for dip. I did not wash the shrooms in water. Big no no. I just wiped them off with a paper towel. After making the filling, I placed it and the shrooms in zip-lock bags. Once I arrived at Christmas dinner, I snipped the bag with the filling and piped it into the shrooms that had been placed on a large cookie sheet. This recipe should be cooked on-site unless your party is next door or across the street. As other reviewers suggested; DO NOT WASH MUSHROOMS IN WATER!!!

FYI to the reviewer who had too much moisture in this dish:  I don't use fresh mushrooms a lot but have read that mushrooms absorb moisture when washed, so should be washed and immediately, thoroughly dried.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just made a triple serving of this for the first time for my Christmas party. It was a huge hit. I was crunched on time on the day of the party so I made the stuffing (minus the crab) the day before and let it sit in fridge. Then added crab next day, put in ziplock back and piped into each mushroom. Then sprinkled with breadcrumbs. I used crimini mushrooms which look more fancy and brown better than the traditional mushroom. I took tips from different reviews and added crab meat and green onions during the saute process. They were a bit too cheesy for me, but everyone else seemed to love it. They disappeared off the table. I assumed about 3 per person for appetizers.

I have taken these mushrooms to every party and they are always the first thing to go.  I sauteed garlic and chopped onions and threw in a frozen crab patty.  When that mixture cooled, I added the rest of the ingredients.  Dip the mushroom caps in melted butter before filling and putting on a cookie sheet.  The result is very rich, but a HUGE HIT!

text:
These were absolutely delicious! I initially halved the recipe because I was only using 4 large Portabello mushrooms. I made the cheesy filling, and realized I didn't have enough to stuff them, so I had to go back and make more! I spooned the filling on, topped it with some thinly-sliced extra-sharp Cheddar, then sprinkled some seasoned breadcrumbs on top. I added a splash of white wine to the baking pan which softened the mushroom bottoms nicely, and also added some subtle flavor. I will definitely make these again. Thanks, Angie!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This recipe was a hit, gone in 10 minutes.  I doubled the recipe and used 2 lbs. of mushrooms.  I took some other reviewers advice and used only 3/4 of the cream cheese called for and added about 3/4 of a cup of breadcrumbs.  I only used 1/2 the cayenne pepper called for and they still had a little kick to them.  I also sprinkled some breadcrumbs on top.  But the best advice was after making the stuffing to put it in a ziploc bag and cut the corner off and squeeze the stuffing into the mushroom caps.  It was so easy this way and you can just throw the mess away.  Thanks for the recipe, I will be making it for years to come.

text:
Excellent!
The cayenne I had was a fresh jar, so it was pretty strong; but since we like it spicey, I think I'll add a little more next time.  Our guests commented that there was just enough "bite" to it with the 1/4 tsp, though.
I added some extra garlic as well as a 6-oz can of crab.  The filling was just the right amount for the giant "gourmet" mushrooms rather than the standard size - well, and extra 4 since there was the crab in the mixture, too.  I can't wait to try stuffing Portabellas with it!
